editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE FLOATING ISLAND: A TRAGI-COMEDY, Acted before his Majeſty at OXFORD, Aug. 29. 1636. By the Students of CHRIST-CHURCH.
Written by WILLIAM STRODE, late Orator of the Univerſity of OXFORD.
The Aires and Songs ſet by Mr. HENRY LAVVES, ſervant to his late Majeſty in his publick and private Muſick.
LONDON, Printed by T. C. for H. Twiford in Vine-court Middle-Temple, N. Brooke at the Angel in Cornhill, and J. Place at Furnivals-Inne-gate. 1655.

div.head: To the Reader.
div.p:
BEfore you read ſo farre as the Prologue, be pleaſed to conſider this Tragi-comedy was both written and preſented above eighteen years ſince; and if now it ſeem (in Language or Plot) to fit theſe times, it muſt be by Propheſie, the Author alſo himſelfe having been long dead. He wrote it at the inſtance of thoſe who might command him; elſe he had ſcarce condeſcended to a Play, his ſerious thoughts being fill'd with notions of deeper conſideration. 'Tis ſufficient for its worth that the beſt lik'd it beſt; the reſt (eſpecially thoſe great ones of the weaker Sect) ſhould claim no lawful Judicature over it, ſince it was not written for them, though they thought themſelves too ſeverely dealt with, which yet was an injury to the Author as well as his Poem. Were this tranſlated into Latin or Italian, it would be grateful to foraign Wits; and if at home it finde leſſe welcome, 'tis becauſe there is not ſo much true wit among us as was or ought to be. It is not now inſcribed to any for Protection, but left dedicated (as it was by the Author when it was firſt born) to the Authors noble Patron. If you bid this welcome, you'l be gainers by it; for then you'l encourage us to publiſh other Pieces of this Authors, which (we dare ſay) will convince you to ſay (what the beſt and moſt knowing of this Nation have confeſſed) that our Author was one of the
〈◊〉 judicious wits of England. Farewell.

div.head: To my moſt Honoured Patron, Sir JOHN HELE, Knight.
div.l: THis Draft at once cry'd Up and Down amain
By divers men, up by the ſame again
At divers times, hath planely found thereby
That it hath cenſur'd been Tumultuouſly.
Twixt Actors and Spectators did appear
Small difference; and through a Jealous fear
The Scaffold play'd the Stage; to ſay't I'm loth,
Affection againſt Reaſon play'd in both.
Yet Reaſon at a neerer view gain'd ſway,
The Cenſure ended juſt as doth the Play.
After this various Fate, becauſe indeed
Of pleaſing more then Four there was ſmall heed,
From Court and Oxford home it comes to you,
Secure of Reaſon and Affection too.
You lent the Author; and tis therefore juſt
The work ſhould yeeld you Tribute for your Truſt:
If Friends make wits, and wit-wrights Poets be,
Then This is His, and He your Poetry.

closer.signed: Your moſt Humble and moſt affectionate Servant, WILLIAM STRODE.

div.head: Authori Illuſtri.
div.l: MIlle modis ſuperare Tibi conceditur aſtra,
Quae ſolùm caelo ſplendida ſunt nitido:
Dum Tua lux tenebras, et opaca nube receſſus
Invenit umbroſos, et ſine ſole vias.
Gemmula nocte micans non eſt vulgar bus apta
Auribus, aſpectum Principis illa decet.
Haud minus iſta Tui Comaedia Principe digna,
Nec niſi Regali conſpicienda foro,
Tranſtulit in Scenam quae res penetralibus imi

Pectoris incluſas, implicitum
que nefas.
Ipſe oculus mundi noſtris valedicit ocellis,
Cum ſemel occiduos aequore merſit equos:
Ter ſex (STRODE) tuus ſolares ſplendor in annos
Fulſit, et in dubio lumine fulget adhuc.

Tu tamen ecclipſin pateris, ſignum
que futuri
Deliquium noſtri funeris illud erat.

div.head: After the Appearance of a FLOATING ISLAND, Enter the Prologue, as coming out of the Sea. To the King and Queenes Majeſty.
div.l: WHatever Element we light upon,
(Great Monarch & bright Queen) 'tis yours alone.
Shook from my ſtation on that giddy Shore,
That flotes in Seas, in wretchedneſſe much more,
I hardly ſcap'd to tell what ſtormes ariſe
Through rage of the Inhabitants: mine eyes
Behold a wonder; Bluſtring Tempeſts there,
Yet Sun and Moon fair ſhining both ſo neer.
Should your Land ſtagger thus, I wiſh the Age,
Might end ſuch acting ſooner then the Stage:
Yet in theſe Tumults you ſhall onely ſee
A tottring Throne held firme by Majeſtie.

div.head: To the Ʋniverſity,
Before whom it was afterwards acted.
div.l: WHich is more waving, yonder Sea, or Land,
Or Paſſions dwelling there, we doubt; but ſtand
Here firm and ſafe; for bluſtring Tempeſts there
We ſee in every eye, fair clearneſſe here.
The Sun and Moon, more out of ſight then minde,
Have for our comfort left theſe Stars behinde.
We hope to finde Spectatours, and we may,
For you'l not act the Humours of the Play;
Or fret at Paſſions e're you read them calm'd
In the next word. Your ſtomacks feele no Qualm
Riſing through ſmell of rude Philoſophy:
Nor ſhall you finde much more then to deſcry
An Academick Birth. The Royal race
Of Auſtria thinks the ſwelling lip a grace,
And would not loſe that mark by which 'tis known;
Men love the Blot which proves the Childe their own.
Whether you come to ſee a Play or hear,
Whether your cenſure ſit in th' Eye or Eare,
Phancy or Judgement, Careleſſe of Event
We aime at Service; cannot miſſe th' Intent.

list.head: The Perſons.
list.item: Hilario his Son a merry jovial Gent.
Deſperato a deſperate Soldier turn'd Phyſitian.
Concupiſcence the luſtful daughter of Amorous:
Fuga the coy daughter of Malevolo.
Morphe the beautous Miſtreſs of Amorous.

div.head: SCENA. I.
div.stage: The Scene turns to the Court of Prudentius.
Enter from ſeveral wayes Sr. Amorous, and Morphe.

sp.speaker: AM.
sp.l: Well met ſweet Morphe,
Empreſſe of my heart,
And all hearts elſe, if made of fleſh like mine.
You muſt not paſſe untouch'd.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: What mean you Sir?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: To print you Mine;

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Hands off Sir Amorous.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Why ſhould ſuch coyneſſe wrinkle ſuch a Brow?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Why ſhould ſuch boyſtrous incivility
Defile your Courtſhip? All your courtly Arts
Of Singing, Playing, Dancing, Poetry,
Will grow ſuſpected pleaders of meer Luſt:
Forbeare for my ſake: this rude force in you
May chance to blot a white repute in me.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: The blot Ile thus rub out.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Ile waſh it thus.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: How can the eye, that ſees not love the light?
Blame your own beauty if you blame my Love.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: I blame th' Expreſſion.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: If the thing be good,
Expreſſion makes it better.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Yes, if chaſt,

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Chaſt Love is nothing.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Nothing to th' unchaſt.
Forbeare I pray, and feare a neere example.
Do you not know the King hath taught the Paſſions
Within this Floating Iſle more modeſty,
By baniſhing your child Concupiſcence?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Others perhaps ſhall quickly know I know it,
And that I know it as rough tyranny.
What for a trick of youth ſuch Diſcipline?
Doth breeding Subjects call for Baniſhment?
Or giving life deſerve a civil Death?
Hold; ſtand; in vain you ſtrive; I am reſolv'd;
Should now the King look on, and call a Kiſſe
Treaſon, ſhould poyſon puniſh this ſwet touch,
Thus far I durſt preſume.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Shame on your rudeneſs.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Are not our Eyes and Lipps and touch our own,
Not to be uſ'd without a ſpecial warrant?
At length we ſhall not ſatisfie meere Nature,
Nor ſpit without a Counſel. If my Girle
Pertake my ſpirit, then like me ſhe'l try,
What fury Love can in the Paſſions raiſe,
To ſhake this Stoick from his chaire of Rule.
Ile move my Fellows.

div.head: SCENA II.
div.stage: Enter to him Irato, Malevolo, Audax.

sp.speaker: Ir.
sp.l: How? not fight this Duel?
Duel forbidden to the Valiant?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Some other cauſe, it ſeemes, moves theſe already.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Be ſure, Irato, by Prudentius law
Perſonal Valour now is nothing worth.
Hope with his Pen, Sr. Timerous with his knife,
Or Deſperato's man with ſingle Halter
May paſſe in equal ranke with you, or me,
Or Captain Audax.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Not with me, I tro.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Yes, if this Law ſhould ſtand.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Not ſo however.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Not if?

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: If to a generous Paſſion?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: I ſee theſe ſparkes are glowing. Noble Sparkes,
Let Amorous adde fire. Love burnes with Hate.
Thy Hand Malevolo, and 'gainſt the King.

sp.speaker: Ir.
sp.l: Why what's your grief?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: My Daughters Baniſhment.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Great cauſe: yet none need preſs a ſingle grief:
We finde our ſelves all pinch'd of liberty:
We walk in chaines, call'd Juſtice, Temperance,
Such ruſty curbs; and none can further ſtart
Then the ſtrict keeper will allow us length.

sp.speaker: Ir.
sp.l: Tis ſo; we're us'd like Dogs, or ring'd like Beares;
Whither Prudentius leades us we muſt follow:
But if we take a looſe, or ſwell and roar,
We muſt be whip'd for't; Sirs, Prudentius whips us.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Can this be brook'd by them that draw the Sword?

sp.speaker: Ir.
sp.l: And amongſt them, by one that will exact
Life for a word, pay death for crabbed lookes?

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: And amongſt them, by one that ſcales the wall,
That ſwims in Armour, flies againſt the mouth
Of thundring Ordinance? muſt alſo He,
Muſt He be ordered by a ſit ſtill thus?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: So he hath been. For my part, if I broach
Some biting Libel, venemous word or Book
Againſt ſome proſprous Object which I hate,
My Eares are queſtioned. Locks which I have ſcorn'd
Muſt hide my Eare ſtumps.

sp.speaker: Ir.
sp.l: And me thinkes I ſpy ſome want upon your Noſe.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Is your ſpleene up?
Rage for your ſelfe. You alſo may remember
Brave Lord Irato when you hardly kept
Your Neck. Some fellow Peers, for as few blowes,
Have loſt it quite.

sp.speaker: Ir.
sp.l: My Veynes will burſt.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: And Captaines
Not to be numbred; All as bold and ſtout
As Audax here, for undertaking reskues,
And following them too far in open ſtreetes,
Have been caſheered of Lberty and Life.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: But ſhall not be again. Ile hang the Law.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Then as for you, Sr. Amorous, you may talk
Not onely of your Daughters Baniſhment,
But of your Siſters whip'd, your carred Aunts,
And Mulcts upon your ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: The truth to tell,
My hard reſtraint is worſt of all. I live (If it be life) confin'd to mine own Bed: Prudentius bridles up my mouth from kiſſing,
Yea and from ſpeech, and calls that ſtinting manners.
I cannot caſt a faire inviting look,
But he pulls back the Nerve. I ſcarce dare think,
Or ſigh beyond my ſtint. One Sigh a day
Is all that I muſt ſpend for her that keepes
And may command my breath. Prudentius
Locks up my winde like Aeolus; 'tis calm'd,
And may not iſſue forth to bear a whiſper.

sp.speaker: Ir.
sp.l: Mend your Compariſon. Prudentius
Like Aeolus? No, Aeolus ſometimes
Permitts a Tempeſt: does Prudentius ſo?

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: The Paſſions cannot ſtretch beyond his line,
But they are cenſured, Perturbations call'd,
Breakers of Peace; if calm'd, they nothing are:
We loſe both Name and Nature by reſtraint.

sp.speaker: Ir.
sp.l: For what's a Lord I ask you but his Anger?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Or what's a great man but oppreſſion?

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: A Captain but his Cutting?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: And a Knight
What but his Pleaſure? O this froſt of Reaſon
Hath numd my Joynts. I that with ſprightly vigour
Dancing to pleaſe my Miſtreſs, could have roſe
To fetch her from the Moon (had ſhe been there)
Or as ſhe ſtood ſalute her, now have loſt
Thoſe active legs, and not by doing ſervice
To any Creature but Prudentius.
I live a Hermite in the Court; to me
It ſeemes a Colledg or a Nunnery.

sp.speaker: Ir.
sp.l: To me a Priſon.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: A meer Schoole to me.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: To me an Inquiſition: worſe: a Hell.
Where Objects ſtill we meet, and may not reach.
You Amorous like Tantalus behold
Two red white Apples in a well made face,
Which you as ſoon may touch as reach the Sun;
Which doth but ſcorch the gazer.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Ile to Hell:
Tis leſſe to ſterve for Apples then for Cheekes.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: You being ſtir'd Irato thirſt for blood,
And thirſt you may, but not be ſatisfied:
You muſt take blowes and beare'em; your Reward
(O poor!) is to orecome by ſuffering;
As now I kick you; ſtand: you muſt not rage,
For this is Patience; now I pull your Noſe;
You muſt not fume, leaſt you impatient prove.

sp.speaker: Ir.
sp.l: Let me kill thee, or ſerve Prudentius ſtill.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: you muſt keep Peace. I ſpeak but as a Friend;
And onely tell what you have told your ſelfe.
You Audax, like Ixion, though you dare
To ſet on Heaven, muſt wheele about your ſelfe
When Reaſon bids you.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Audax will run on
Though thunder meet him.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Yes; but I my ſelfe
Like Titius vainly feed the Vultur Hate
With mine own heart, and wreck it not on others,
Thoſe Favourits which I hate. Shall this be ever?

sp.speaker: Ir.
sp.l: How long ſhall I like to a painted George
Advance my idle Sword? What muſt I ſtrike
Like Iack o'th clock-houſe, never but in ſeaſon?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: How long ſhall I like a grim Statue ſtand,
Look hatred and uſe none? Prudentius
Hath he Meduſa's head?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Hey ho, how long!

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: How long ſhall I like a fell Maſtiff held,
Yelp for the glorious danger that I love!
Water it ſelfe if bounded in too ſtreight,
Will foame and ſwell and breake thick bonds of Rock.
I wiſh we Paſſions were as ſtrong as water.

div.head: SCENA. III.
div.stage: Enter to them Hilario Singing, Dancing and Paſſing by.

lg.l: And dancing will ſhake my hair:
And a head not needing a cloute,
And a wreath of thornes without.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: The Boy may be our Tutor. Hilario my Boy!

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: We were taking care how thou may'ſt be merry thus alwaies; never be check'd for drinking, for ſinging, or for playing thy prankes.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: I imagin your deſign: and thereto promiſe, give, grant, let, ſet and ſubmit my full aſſent and conſent: In witneſſe whereof here's my hand with a clap, and my ſeale with a kiſſe; Your ſon and ſervant Hilario.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: But ſtay, whence now?

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.l: From my blubbering Siſter Concupiſcence;
who deſired me forſooth
To arme and conduct her to Lady Phancy.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: And whether bound?

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.l: I go to be merry with or upon
Melancholico and Deſperato,
Either to quicken their dumps, or by laughing
at their dulneſſe to heighten my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Where are they?

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.l: Not far; cloſe by; here at the Hart.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Courteous Sir, ſend them hither,

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.l: I ſhall or will Sir.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: We muſt no longer ripe up greivances,
But think of Remedy.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Paſſions muſt not ſtay.

sp.speaker: Ir.
sp.l: Why with a murraine do we ſtay to ſay ſo?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: In briefe do all conſent to free themſelves
From this oppeſſion?

sp.speaker: Ir.
sp.l: What a Queſtion's that?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Give a Command that it be ask'd no more.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: We all conſent.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: All are not here.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Indeed
We want two ſerviceable men now ſent for.

sp.speaker: Ir.
sp.l: Delayes intolerable!

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: We want beſides Sir Timerous Fear all.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Wee'l force that dowty Knight
To know his good when all is done; and ſo
Prevent his Treaſon.

sp.speaker: Ir.
sp.l: Conſultation too.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: And where is Livebyhope?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: No matter where.
His hopes will make him turn to any ſide
That ſhall ſucceed.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: For femal Paſſions,
Their fortune lies in ours.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Then to proceed,
The way to free our ſelves lies, thus, or thus;
Kill, or dethrone Prudentius.

sp.speaker: Ir.
sp.l: I begin To think on Sr. Raviliack, and Sr. Garnett.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: The boldeſt way is ſafeſt.

sp.speaker: Ir.
sp.l: Yes, if bloodieſt.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Or if he will eſcape.

sp.speaker: Ir.
sp.l: Let him go far enough.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Then who ſhall do the feare?

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: I.

sp.speaker: Ir.
sp.l: I, or elſe
Ile kill ſome other; what? ſhould I for get
My ancient Trade of killing?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Let him doo't
Who firſt hath opportunity.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: To this We all muſt ſweare.

sp.speaker: Ir.
sp.l: By all the wounds which on my fleſh are ſcor'd,
And all the ghoſts I've made.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: By all attempts
And all the mines of Bullets in my Entrals;

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: By all my pangs of hare and black deſignes;

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: By all the goodly Nymphes, and Morphe chief.

div.head: SCENA IIII.
div.stage: Enter to them Prudentius, Intellectus Agens, and Liveby hope with Attendents.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.l: D'ee long for action? have ye too much Peace?
Orecloy'd with bleſſings? you Malevolo
Bend hate againſt th' unjuſt.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: My hand is crampt;
Strike Audax.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: O his brow! I turn to feare.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.l: You Amorous love true beauty, Honeſty.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Thy ſpleene Irato.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.l: Thou Irato fight
Meerely for publike peace.

sp.speaker: Ir.
sp.l: Sweetneſſe!

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Witchcraft!

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.l: Audax, be bold, but ſtay till I have bid

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: S't. Liveby hope

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: I muſt attend his Majeſty.

sp.speaker: Int.
sp.l: Goe back, and ſecretly oreheare this meeting.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Ha! What Schooling call you this?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: What Viſion?
That Eye of ſubtil Intellectus Agent
Troubles me ſomewhat; and I doubt of Liveby.

sp.speaker: Ir.
sp.l: Now I could kill my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Now I, Prudentius
He came upon us like the Baſilisk,
Or like a Wolfe; but had we ſeen him firſt—

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: You could not do it then: never by day.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Why ſo?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: You ſaw the cauſe. His flaming Temples
Strike with ſuch charming Power, ſuch ſecret Spells,
That if you ſee the Light upon his Face,
Your ſpirits quaile; it muſt be done by night.
And Deſperato, he muſt be the man.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Why He above All Us?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Tuſh, we are foyld;
Already foyld; and may be ſo again.
Beſides Irato ſpends himſelfe: hee's now
So full of heat, I doubt hee'l then grow cold.
But Deſperato to his miſchief goes
With art and argued reſolution,
Strong in cold blood.

sp.speaker: Ir.
sp.l: I perfectly abhorr
All Judgement, Plo •• s, and Conſultations▪
To canvaſe thoughts, to toile and vexe the
In weighing meanes, and picking out the beſt,
This is as bad as to have ſerv'd Prudentius.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: And how thinks Audax?

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: So. Or elſe I'm mad.
To plot is baſe; and to demurr contrivance
Of things that ſhould be done, as ſoon as thought,
Is fooliſh too. What turn our powder up,
Then ſmother't under ground, then by degrees
Give fire! Such creeping miſcheife hath no luck.

sp.speaker: Ir.
sp.l: Come Martial Law, come Captain Martial Law

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: And wiſe Malevolo, when have you e're heard
Of great attempts without the hand of Audax?
Come wee'l too't preſently.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Even as you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: (in ſecret) I ſweat with hearing.
Il now run with this Leaſt I may come too ſhort of telling more.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Onely this word.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Then yet I'le ſtay.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Be ſure,
If you miſcarry we are all undone.
Goe with Ʋlyſſes in this night-attempt,
Be each of you to him a Diomed.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Stay till they come.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Lo here they are. Who elſe?

div.head: SCENA V.
div.stage: Enter to them Melancholico, Deſperato and Sr. Timerous.

sp.speaker: Ir.
sp.l: What and Sr. Timerous too? Come▪ mend your pace.
What? doth Prudentius moderate your feet?
And make you ſnayles as well as ſlaves?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Free Paſſions,
(So ye muſt be) we know your greivances.
Brother Melancholy, diſcreet you are,
But not expreſſive; unprefer'd you are,

Becauſe preciſe; but ſay, would you with
State
Inſold your armes; look ſad, and feele content;
Live careful over bags, retire your ſelfe
To ſolemn greife in Temples of delight,
Sigh in a Siſters boſom, and complain
Of Perſecution at a plenteous Feaſt?

sp.speaker: Ir.
sp.l: Yes, yes. I'le anſwer for him.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Sooth, you may.
Sadneſſe is pleaſant, but the cauſe is not.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: And Deſperato, once my old Comrad,
Once Noble, and again to be the ſame,
But now as void of caſh as of imployment,
Would you, in Peace forgot, bard of a Penſion,
Having no lands but bare high-wayes, now run
All hazards for new Fortune?

sp.speaker: Deſp.
sp.l: Yes apace.

sp.speaker: Ir.
sp.l: Why parly then? can he not firſt draw blood?
Do Cutters ask what money have you firſt?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Blood and Cutters? his ſpeech is rough.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: hee's mad.
Say on.

sp.speaker: Ir.
sp.l: Nought's done through ſuch long talke.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Such Choler.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Wouldſt thou have power to raiſe more flames then Nero,
To fire the World, prevent his final doome,
Stare awfully, ſtab others with applauſe,
Hang, drown thy ſelfe, to immortality.

sp.speaker: Deſp.
sp.l: Such change I long for; rows'd from Lethargy
I am reviv'd.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Thou lyeſt, thou art not yet.
Hold, hold thy hand: I did but tempt thy mettle,
To ſearch the truth.

sp.speaker: Deſp.
sp.l: And Sir, 'tis well you ſay ſo.

sp.speaker: Ir.
sp.l: This Bully,s right, why now I'm pleas'd

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Sr. Tim.
My fellow Knight, you know (but do not tremble)
How oft the King hath miſimpos'd on you
Thoſe dreadful, thoſe horrible, terrible

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Good Sir.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Thoſe heart-labouring imployments,
Which Audax beg'd.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: I pray.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: He ſought thereby
Meerely to vexe and to diſgrace your ſpurr▪
But wouldſt thou hug thy Pillow or thy Love
Without diſturbance, or the noiſe of danger?
How ſay'ſt?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: I love to live, and love in ſafety.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Then in a word.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: He firſt kick hence this Knight,
Hee'l prove a five through feare; his trembling humour
Will ſhake our ſecrets out.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Which to prevent,
He ſtirs not from this company.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Then know,
Our common medicine is Prudentius ruine.
Laſt comers, do ye twiſt in full conſent?

sp.speaker: Mel. & Deſp.
sp.l: We do.

sp.speaker: Ir.
sp.l: then kiſſe the Sacramental Sword.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Sr. Tim. you came unſought, but being come,
You muſt conſent, or will be beaten too't.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: I, I do conſent—but caution muſt be had;
This is no common ſport: what Engines uſe ye?

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Not you, be ſure. Will Deſperato joyne
With me and this brave Count?

sp.speaker: Deſp.
sp.l: Yes, and ſtrike home.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Then for the time: we think cloſe midnight beſt.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: And fitteſt; cauſe the crowned
Fox is watchful.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Be ſure you take diſguiſe to paſſe unknown,
Though it be night.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: O wit and valour both!
Vizards to Paſſengers will be but ſignes
Hang'd out to move ſuſpicion; and to leave
Him ignorant whom we aſſault is loſſe▪
Unto the glory of our bold revenge.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: What ſhall be done with Memor the Recorder,
One whom I hate, yet have no reaſon for't,
Like an old debt-book, or mine own Conſcience▪
Shall he be blotted out, or ſhall he ſtand?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Alas he's all Record, Example, Cuſtome,
What's done Quadrageſimo primo Henrici tertii,
And theſe ſute more with Paſſion then with Reaſon.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: What ſhall be done with Common ſenſe the Judge?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: He alſo more inclines to ſenſe then Prudence,
Leanes to the Commons rather then the King.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: As for the reſt, they ne're ſhall trouble us;
Cut off the head, we need not feare the Members.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Who ſhall ſucceed? I mean, in place, and ſhew,
Not in the tyranny of ſtrict Command;
Who ſhall aſſemble, lead, incourage us,
And give ſome faſhion to our Commonwealth?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: What ſay to Fancie? will not Fancie do't?

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: No better choice: for Fancie neereſt is
To unyoak'd Paſſion.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: And 'tis moſt proper,
That ſince by Paſſion this revolt is made
From Reaſon unto Senſe, the Rule ſhould paſſe
From man to Woman.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: She, ſhe, Fancie ſhe.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: (in ſecret) O now for wings like thought, this to relate
Firſt to the Agent of Prudentius;
And then to beare firſt newes to new Queen Fancie.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: She, Fancie's Queen.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: She'l be a pleaſant Miſtreſſe
Rather then Governeſſe, leading each Paſſion
Whether himſelfe inclines. Nay ſhe'l invent
New Objects for their ſeveral content.

div.head: SCENA VI.
div.stage: Enter to them Groome of the Chamber.

sp.speaker: Groo.
sp.l: Silence through all the Court, the King would reſt.

sp.speaker: Deſp.
sp.l: Let him Eternally.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: The time growes nigh.
You three to th' task of Blood: the reſt to Fancy.

sp.speaker: Groo.
sp.l: I doubt this earneſt talk portends no good,
The buſineſſe hath been hot.—

div.stage: Enter form the Bedchamber Prudentius Crown'd, and Intellectus Agens.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.l: We would be private.
Liveby the Relator is moſt creditable.

sp.speaker: Int.
sp.l: A right ingenuous man.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.l: And you have ſent him
To take advantage of the changing State,
With Caveat to reſerve his heart for Us.

sp.speaker: Int.
sp.l: The Pinch and my beſt thoughts did ſo inſtruct me.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.l: Tis well, I dearely thank your ſharp obſervance,
Suſpecting Treaſon by their ſtartled brows;
And then your art of finding out, and now
Your Providence for our Reſtabliſhment.
But O, O this ungrateful Rout, whom I have taught
Both how to Feare and Love, and what to Loath,
Wherefore to Greive and Joy, and in what place
To rouſe their anger and audacity
By Rule and Circumſtance, and with ſuch Sweetneſſe
As might befit a Wooer more then King.
Have I theſe Vipers bred within my Breſt
With greater Care and Pangs then can a Mother
The Childe within her womb? have I broke ſleep
Toſs'd after ſlumbers, early roſe, and ſpent
The day from Sun to Sun in painful Counſel;
Sent Birds about their Coaſts, ſent Eyes and Tongues
Abroad the world, to watch and guard,
and work,
And keep all ſafe, and make them great, for This
For This Reward? Ask Heaven and Earth, if I
Have not with utmoſt care procur'd them Bread,
Cloth, Health, Peace, Manners, and Religion!
For Prudence is the womb and Forg of all
This mortal bliſſe. What ere I took from Them
Was for their uſe; like Vapour now exhal'd,
And ſoon return'd in Showers to fat their Land.
Oft have I bore them under both theſe wings,
One under each, when they inclin'd to Fury,
Would puſh each other down a Precipice,
Not ſteep like th' Alpes, but ſteep on either ſide,
There on a narrow ridg, an edg, a Thrid,
(Such is the meane, ſo plac'd betwixt two Gulfes)
I bore them in their Strife. For this and more
They have not pay'd (what's cheaper?) Single Duty.
Nothing but Grudgings, Whiſpers, Evil words:
Theſe are their Thankes.

sp.speaker: Int.
sp.l: The greater glory yours:
What Crown like This to govern out of almes!

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.l: But now they ſeek the Crown; my life they ſeek.

sp.speaker: Int.
sp.l: They'l beg hereafter that you'l take the Rule,
Which now they wreſt out of your hands.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.l: Perhaps.

sp.speaker: Int.
sp.l: Meane while your life is ſafe.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.l: And while 'tis ſafe,
Though they forget their Duty, I, le not leave
A Fathers care, but will be ſtill a King
In love, though not in power.

sp.speaker: Int.
sp.l: This is a ſigne
Of future greatneſſe. Then caſt off this Crown
As but the ſheddings of renewing State,
Now to be burniſhed. Leave it on your Pillow:
For that they ſeek. But it return'd ſhall be
With double ſervice both of Heart and Knee.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.l: Be Thou my Prophet.

sp.speaker: Int.
sp.l: Ware; the Caitiffes come.

div.head: SCENA VII.
div.stage: Enter Audax, Deſperato, Irato with Swords: the firſt bearing a Torch.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: This Torch muſt out, or ſome muſt blind their eyes;
And look not all at once, leaſt all be
ſtruck.
The Chamber's here.

sp.speaker: Deſp.
sp.l: Come ſet your Points
And Poſtures right; ſtand ſure.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.l: Why ſhould not I
Step in, and daunt them?

sp.speaker: Int.
sp.l: Tis not ſafe to tempt
United Impudence too far: withdraw.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.l: When Folly's ripe, Ile to my Diligence.

sp.speaker: Int.
sp.l: And I to ſerve you with Intelligence.
I'le guide you to ſome Cloyſter.

sp.speaker: Ir.
sp.l: Now: there's the Neſt.

sp.speaker: Deſp.
sp.l: But what? the Eagle's flowne.

sp.speaker: Ir.
sp.l: Damn'd Trechery!
Treaſon amongſt us Traytors!

sp.speaker: Deſp.
sp.l: Leſſe Reſolution
Then mine had ſerv'd this Task.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: How'ere my Lads,

Our Labour is not loſt. Here's what we
ſeek for.

sp.speaker: Ir.
sp.l: Thus when the Beaver ſmells the Hunters aime,
He throwes away the price of his eſcape.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Now ſhall I offer what affront I pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Ir.
sp.l: Ile ſtab with honour at what word miſlikes me.

sp.speaker: Deſp.
sp.l: No Peace ſhall ſtand unleſſe our pleaſure make it.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Fancie, we come. Stay, hark, ſtand, hark. This ſound

div.l: The Sirens make, 'cauſe Fancie ſhall be crown'd.

div.head: SCENA. I.
div.l: The Scene turns to Fancies Court.

sp.speaker: Conc.
sp.l: The Day appears in Scarlet; and the Sun
Seconds the luſter of our riſing Queen.
I nere long'd more for night, then for this morning.

sp.speaker: Fug.
sp.l: Twill be to you a double day, and bring
Your Miſtreſſe Majeſty, you Liberty.

sp.speaker: Conc.
sp.l: Fuga, the caſe is alterd; he that baniſh'd,
Himſelfe is vaniſh'd. Thus the King and I,
Or I and he, are up and down like Buckets.
Ha wench! theſe Moral men are taught,
I tro,
What 'tis to wrong kind hearts. Return with me
Periwigs, Powders, Fucuſes for Ladies,
Chioppiens for ſhort, for crooked Farthingals;
For tainted Artificial breath; Teeth moveable;
Such as may ſerve a Family by turns,
To eat, and laugh abroad: now wellcome helps
For all decayes of Nature, Arts for allurement;
Be licenc'd Ladies for Variety
Now to miſtake your Servant, Uſher, Page,
For your own Lords, and without Hereſie
In marri'd State.

sp.speaker: Fug.
sp.l: Fie Madam how you talk!

sp.speaker: Conc.
sp.l: How talk I Madam Simpers? do not thus
And broader too as mincing Dames as you,
When met together? Do you ſee your Servant?

div.head: SCENA II.
div.stage: Enter to them Sr. Timerous with a Paper.

sp.speaker: Conc.
sp.l: Sr. Timerous Fear-all inches and inches to you
Iuſt like a Spy.

div.stage: He ſteals to Fuga and offers the Paper, ſhe refuſes; Concup. ſnatches and reades it.

sp.speaker: Fug.
sp.l: And ſtill he comes in ſecret
Leaſt he be ſpied.

sp.speaker: Conc.
sp.l: What's this? a ſilent motion?
The Bill hung out will ſhew us what it is.
Lady, I dare not with the praiſe of arts
With any thing but Love aſſay your parts;
Which are ſo rare, that when I ſtrive to write,
The ſcant Expreſſion ſeems not Love but ſpite.
Well wrot Sr. Tim.

sp.speaker: Fug.
sp.l: You cannot ſay well ſpoke.

sp.speaker: Conc.
sp.l: Can you not uſe your mouth? no way, Sr Tim.?
Why do you love? you are not fit to love;
Think me your Miſtreſſe; now addreſſe your ſelfe
In form befitting.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Hum!

div.stage: He offers to Salute and ſteps back again; ſhe makes to him.

sp.speaker: Conc.
sp.l: I muſt make up
Your will with my performance.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Hum—I fear Fuga will frown.

sp.speaker: Conc.
sp.l: Thy Mother was a Fuga.
Nor give nor take? not in a faire Salute?

Tongue-tide and Lip-bound too? O that
it were
In faſhion for my Sex, my Sex, to wooe.

sp.speaker: Fug.
sp.l: Lady, you ſeem to me in word and action
Too looſe and open.

sp.speaker: Conc.
sp.l: My Complexion
Is I confeſſe the ſame with Meſſaline's;
We might have layn together in one Egg
As well a Helena and Clytemneſtra.
To me no ſuch deſire as of our Like,
No Joy like Union. But your eares and age
Want breeding yet;
I'm ſorry for offending:
I thought I knew my Sex; but if I do not,
I know my ſelfe.

div.head: SCENA III.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: What here ye whirlygigs, while Queen Fancie calls you? Where's Concupiſcence, where's Concupiſcence? After all your Starching, Quilling, Turning, Seeking, Pinning; after your Jury of Pedlars, Tirewomen, Lacemakers and Semſters, ſtill where's Concupiſcence? Your Lady Fancie findes many greivous defects; there wants a Pin or two at leaſt. One of her ribband Fancies are looſe; a long haire hath un weav'd it ſelfe out of its curl'd Spheare, and paſſionatly broke forth out of Order. Fly, fly, ye Baggaſes.

sp.speaker: Fug.
sp.p: Baggaſes?

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: As for my Siſter, ſhee's one I'm ſure: She colours for it; her willow gowne with • ay me forſaken wretch is a Challeng, a meer Challeng to all pittiful-minded Amoroſes: She's true touch, all the world can tell. Wu'd you were ſo too Lady for Sr. Tim's ſake. Stay Fuga, you muſt ſtay one minute; for I muſt ſhew on you how Sr. Tim. muſt wooe.

sp.speaker: Fug.
sp.p: I ſee every one's ready to be a Dunces Teacher.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Thus Sr.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: This is Loves Trenchmore.

sp.speaker: Fug.
sp.p: Fie on you all.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.l: A prity wench. Sr. Tim, but that ſhe's ſawe'd
With ſome of her Fathers Humour; this coyneſſe calls her
Ma'evolo's Daughter. But what of that?
Every coy laſſe is of Cockeril condition,
And muſt be woo'd as Cockerils fight, chaſe and retreate;
And then ſheel love you like your ſhadow;
Fly thou, ſheel follow; follow thou, ſheel fly,
For I ſay no, and for her no ſay I.
Thus when a long time ye have turn'd backs one to another,
Ye may at length turn faces.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Sr. I ſhall ſometimes
Repaire to your wit for my direction.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: You may—and I ſhall readily afford it to your folly

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: The Queen's at hand.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: And they not ready yet with their tedious Phantaſtticalia!

div.head: SCENA IIII.
div.stage: Enter alſo Fancie, Concupiſcence going backward before, carrying an Ʋmbrella over her, Fuga and Memor following. After a while the Solemnity.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Iuſt in that Poſture, Madam, as you walk'd,
Horacius kill'd three men.

sp.speaker: Conc.
sp.p: Three? what no more? Why, I have kill'd three hundred, would three thouſand.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.p: Where's that appearance which we have expected? And where's my glaſſe?

sp.speaker: Fug.
sp.p: You have one in your watch.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.p:
That's not big enough. Run Fuga; come hither
Concupiſcence, pin this handſomer.

sp.speaker: Ir.
sp.p: Au. Deſp. (within) Ile beare The Crown or nothing.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: (within) I the Crown or nothing.

sp.speaker: Liv
sp.p: (Enters and out again) Ile fit each Paſſion to his own content.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Boy, fill up the Time with noiſe.

sp.speaker: Boy.

lg.l: Hail thou great Queen of varous Humours,
Some loving hearts, ſome raging tumours,
As theſe in heaping honours on you.

sp.stage: Enter in the midſt of the ſong Amorous uſhering the ſolemnity, Irato bearing the Sword, Malevolo the Scepter; then ſix others bearing ſix Crowns, two in a rank. Firſt Audax on the right hand bearing a Crown of Gold, and with him Poet Ovidian a Lawrel: then Deſperato a Turkiſh Turbant, and with him Timerous a Perſian Cydaris: Laſtly Livebyhope a Crown of all colour'd feathers circled at the bottome with Pearle, and with him Model her Tireman a Coronet of black beaugled wire ſet with black and Silver ſpangles. Having done obeyſance, they ſtand and preſent in Order.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Great goddeſſe, moſt ador'd of men, behold,
Amorous thy lovingſt Paſſion, brings the reſt
To offer at thy Feet Enſignes of State.

sp.speaker: Ir.
sp.l: I that unſheath'd my anger with my Sword
To make thee great, preſent this Sword of Juſtice.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: I that with Plots have wrung this awful Secpter
From other hands, will hold hold it faſt in thine.
Ile finde or make new matter of great ruine
To raiſe thy Throne,

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: This maſſy Crown of Gold,
The price of nightly danger, won by Audax,
Left by Prudentius, let it crown thy Temples,

sp.speaker: Ovid.
sp.l: Elſe let thy ſhining brow recrown this Lawrel,
Worn but by Caeſar Monarch of the world,
And thy Ovidii, makers made of thee.

sp.speaker: Deſp.
sp.l: Let Deſperato wrap thy ſemal head
With Imniu State, the Crown of that grand Seignior
Who worſhips moſt theſe two, Woman and Fate.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: But Timerous brings the Perſian Cydaris,
Which drop'd from Xerxes Temples in his flight.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Liveby a Crown of Feathers here preſents
To repreſent the light and eaſiy yoak,
Which all the Paſſions hope.

sp.speaker: Mod.
sp.l: Model thy Tireman
Offers for company this Crown, not coſtly,
But yet of prety Fancie, new Invention.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: We thank the wit and paynes of all your ſervice.
We'l weare theſe Crownes in turn, and try them all. Liveby, reach hither.—Where's Recorder Memor?

div.stage: Liv. reaches his feathered Crown. Au. reaches the Golden, Mal. the Scepter.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Here.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Firſt take this, the chief true real Crown.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Theſe were the honours which Prudentius wore.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: Were thoſe his honours? they ſhall ne're be mine.
Thoſe onely I except.

sp.speaker: Ir.
sp.l: Wiſely excepted:

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Great Lady, ſay not ſo: put on this Crown,

And with your Head crown it: then let
your Hand
Give Life unto this Scepter, and to Us:

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: Ile rather not be Empreſſe, then aſſume
Or that, or this.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Say ſo?

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.l: Prettieſt of pretties;
We here would have a Queen, and ſhe'l not weare
The Badg and Enſigne that ſhould make her ſo.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: Is none a Prince, but ſhe whoſe head ſupports
The burden of a Crown?

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Indeed Authority
Lies not in this: then Kings could do no more
Without the leave of this Authentick toy
Then can a Conſtable without his ſtaff.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: A Crown would crooke my neck, which for a Realme
I would not marr.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.l: Nor marr that Ruff for three.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: If this condition needs muſt be inforc'd,
I willingly reſign what you conferr.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Then ſome of us ſhall be a gainer by it.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Do not ſo ſlight the labour of your Servants,
Who ventur'd far to gain this wreath; in which
Lies the ſignificance of all the reſt.

sp.speaker: Ir.
sp.l: Let her refuſe once more.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: My Noble friends,
It ſignifies too much, too great a Care,
Too high Command. Should my free wandring thoughts
Be hoop'd and compaſs'd in with weight and care,
Or ſhould that ſtaff keep down your ſprightly humours, Fancie might then be ſtil'd Prudentia.
No; though I reign, provide your ſelves live free.
This onely is my Law, that each man uſe
His proper humour, be it Vice or Vertue,
Inordinate or ſtay'd. Who mindes his pleaſure
Shall beſt deſerve; my ſelfe will teach him how;
And guide him in't. For your own ſakes and mine,
Offer no more that badg of Tyranny.
sp.stage: All but It. Mal. Au. & Deſp.
sp.l: Fancie beyond all Fancie.

sp.speaker: Ir.
sp.l: Plague on Diſſemblers;
Firſt on her ſelfe; then on theſe raſcals here;
Who firſt perſwaded her to take the Crown,
And then admire her for refuſing it.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Pleaſes your highneſſe with your radiant haire
To grace ſome other badg of Majeſty?

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: To ſhew I do not quite reject your Favours,
Nor ſlight the proffered Rule, reach me the Lawrel,
And then the glaſs.ſhe lookes

div.stage: Liv. reaches the Crownes in turn.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Ev'n thus did mighty Caeſar!

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: Ti's too Imperious This.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Wit beyond Caeſars!

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Excellent Lady!

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: Tis too Imperious
If rule it mean; if height of wit, too low:
Tis like a Tavern, Buſh and begs for ſale,
Which Fancy ſcornes. Small Poet, take it you.
What's next? the Turbant.—What a Turk am I now!
Had I with this a large Seraglio,
I'de lend them to Sr. Amorous.—The next.—
This Perſian Cydaris hath made ſome Sophies
That ſcarce were wiſe before: when I ſit next
In Solemn Counſel, Ile weare This.— But now;—
This feather'd Crown like a Mercurial hat
Shall lift me from the ground; herein Ile grace
The preſent Faſhion.—The Tiremans Coronet
May be in Faſhion too; and pitty 'tis not;
I like it well.—But Liveby, tis your Favour
That muſt take place, and give us Majeſty.
Set it on firm, and ſomewhat glancing.—So.
I, marry Sir; why, this befits us right.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.l: Wu'd I had brought my Fooles Cap to preſent her,
My fooles Cap would have gotten the ſtart of Favour
From Live by for ever.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: Thankes Liveby, and Ile ſtudy a Reward.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Your humbleſt Creature.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: This fits the Quality
Of our intended Rule, which ſhall be light,
Light as your Liveby ſaid, and ſoft and ſweet,
And various, and pliable to every paſſion.
I'm bound to All, and much to Amo ous,
And moſt to Liveby For beſides this preſent,
You brought me tidings firſt of this advancement,
And Crown'd me in my Eare. Who likes the newes,
Muſt needs regard the teller.—One I miſſe
Amongſt the Paſſions, Melancholico.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: He ſullen grew becauſe he might not beare
The maſſy Crown.—

div.head: SCENA V.
div.stage: Enter to them Melancholico bringing Fancies Picture Crown'd with Gold. Painter and Muſitian.

sp.speaker: Conc.
sp.l: —Now he hath brought himſelfe.

sp.speaker: Fug.
sp.l: And ſomewhat elſe.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Although I wanted Grace
To plant the maſſy Crown upon your head
In the true ſubſtance, yet I found a way
To crown you in this Picture. Here's the Painter;
And here a try'd Muſitian; men of Arts,
Which Melancholy much affects.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: And I.
But mende your peice. That Crown delights not me.
Some ſudden buſineſſe calls me to conferr
With certain Femal Artiſts!—Liveby,
Take you the keeping of thoſe Ornaments.—

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: What? have we made a ſhittlecock our Queen?

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: Stay, I had quite forgot to ſtrew mine honours
On theſe deſervers. You Malevolo
Be our chief Counſellour: be you Irato
The Lord Controwler: Livebyhope ſhall be
The Maſter of Requeſts: you Amorous
Shall be the Maſter of our Ceremonies;
For which here's Poet, Painter, man of Muſick,
And man of Properties: I give you leave
To uſe them for your ſelfe in wooing Morphe.
But you my Poet whom I well reſpect,
Shall be my Secretary, and you ſhall turn
The long-breath'd ſtile of Proclamation
To Lyrick Verſe.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Moſt underſtanding Queen!

sp.speaker: Ir.
sp.l: A prety Curr! my hands now itch to try
Whether he be true Spaniel breed, or no;
O I could beate and kick him, and ſee whether
He'l fawn then to.—You were not beſt to flatter
Your ſelfe into an Earldom, one degree
Above mine Honour.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Take heed my Lord: he's likely to be great;
A Favourite can hurt.

sp.speaker: Ir.
sp.l: What then? muſt I
Therefore take heed? bid me take heed again,
And it ſhall be the laſt, laſt Caution,
You ere ſhall give. What? give a Lord
good Counſel?

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: The reſt, if they themſelves can finde a way
How I may pleaſure them, I'm crown'd their ſervant:
You know your Law; each man purſue his humour.
Ile rule by Fancie ſince I am Queen Fan;
And uſe as little wiſdom as I can.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: And ſo it ſeemes.

div.stage: Ex. Fan. with her women. Am. Liv. Mem. Poet, Mus.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.l: Ha ha ha ha ha ha—
How merry ſhall I live!—Hil.—

sp.speaker: Paint.
sp.l: Sr. Shall I mend This peice?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Mend! marr, or break it if you will.
Now ſhall I turn far more preciſe then ever,
And praiſe Prudenius dayes throw diſcontent.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Slighted? contemned? bafled? fooles preferd?
I'm well rewarded.

sp.speaker: Ir.
sp.l: Hark Sr. Timerous,
You gave me Counſel.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Out of Love indeed Sir.

sp.speaker: Ir.
sp.l: You gave Prudentius warning to eſcape.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Not I, indeed not I, Sr. Amorous knowes

sp.speaker: Ir.
sp.l: How ere Ile kick thee now, cauſe tis my humour;
Ile take thee to be Liveby, tis my Humour.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: The Queen ſhall know how you
have kick'd my Knighthood.

sp.speaker: Ir.
sp.l: I kick'd thy breech, two foot above thy Knighthood.
I truſt I ſhall have cauſe to kill thee too.
Mean while, to ſtir my choler, Ile controwle Roughly, moſt roughly.

sp.speaker: Deſp.
sp.l: I to feed my humour,
(For little I ſhall have to feed my body)
Muſt run ſome deſperate courſe. The ſtream of Favour
Runs croſſe from me, to Hope and Amcrous.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Did we expoſe our ſelves to utmoſt danger
To gain a Crown for Her that more regards
A Cap and Feather?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: I her Counſellour
Who alters with each puff, more flickering
Then Flag or Streamer? Then Ile write on Sand,
Or print the Aire. But ſtill I wonder much,
How Liveby being abſent from our Counſels,
Carri'd the firſt Intelligence. His telling
In Her eſteem outweighs our Action.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: This ſhewes what women love, the Tong and • atling.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: How ſayes this man of Fate? is Livebyhope,
That primroſe thing, that forward bud, long liv'd?

sp.speaker: Ir.
sp.l: Ha! I think no; unleſſe I may controule him
To be no Favourite.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Men of that calling, If I might counſel them for their beſt ſafety,
Ought not to live too long. For we can hate.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Challeng.

sp.speaker: Ir.
sp.l: Or ſtab.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: And call theſe things our Humours.

sp.speaker: Int.
sp.l: The ſafeſt Armour is un weapon'd boldneſſe.
Thus priviledg'd Ile truſt their ſavage hands.
All happineſſe, that is, true Liberty
Unto the Paſſions; how d'e like your choice?

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Firſt tell us where Prudentius hides himſelfe.

sp.speaker: Int.
sp.l: Within a Sanctuary, where his thoughts
Are ſequeſtred from earthly cares to heaven.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Our choice we like beyond Prudentius,
Juſt ſo, as Fancie Livebys feather'd crown
Beyond my Golden.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: We like the power of chuſing.

sp.speaker: Ir.
sp.l: And ſome variety though join'd with looſing—

sp.speaker: Int.
sp.l: Who ere Uſurps, conſiders not his task,
How he muſt ſooth the loweſt of his villaines,
Give higheſt place and all to every one,
Elſe all will be diſpleas'd. The King ſhall know,
What ſeeds of diſcontent and headlon folly
Appeare already in this warring ſtate.
Clos'd in too ſafe, they broke their hedg; what leſſe
Then wandring now through wretched wilderneſſe?

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: I think your cauſe exceeds the Cogniſance
Of common ſenſe. He like a Juryman
Can onely ſinde and judge the outward fact:
As whether now your kicks look white or blew;
Whether his threatning words were high or low;
What favour follow'd, whether ſweet or ſowre;
Whether the kicks were Rough or gentle; (Rough
Your Grinkling ſayes) Theſe with ſome other notions
Thereto belonging, as the quantity,
The Figure, Number, the ſwift motion,
Or ceaſing of your kicks; theſe he can judge of.
But as for higher ſpeculations
Of Paſſions riſing out of meer conceit,
How it was rais'd, what puniſhment is
due,
This proper lbyelongs to Fancie's audience.
Was there no cauſe?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: None giv'n, but apprehended.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: The worſe for you; this ſhewes there was no malice,
But ſingle heat. Were the kicks thick and many?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Six ſtrong ones in one inſtant.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Still the worſe.
It ſhewes meer heat. What ſaid he, 'twas his humour?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Ev'n ſo.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Yet worſe. Tis Law, that ev'ry Paſſion
May follow his own humour. Anger's his.
Beſides he's writ a Lord: all things conſidered,
I give you counſel to be patient,
To ask if he be pleas'd to give you more;
To break a Tooth, pull Haire, ſtrik out an Eye.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Accept my thankes: I ſee the Law it ſelfe
Is very Timerous againſt great Perſons.—

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: I now can ſee no uſe of Law at all,
Law is caſheer'd: where all things are permitted
What need of plea? what can be call'd unjuſt?
And are not theſe the Popular dayes we look'd for,
When we expected Cunning ſhould be Soveraigne?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: In miſcheif we muſt uſe the men we hate.
You are the man I ſeek. Have you conſider'd
Thoſe State-projections?

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Sr. we want ſome Lawes,
Such as were made for certain Lord Protectors.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Indeed this lawful murder is an Art
Of Excellence, and yet as eaſie too
For Stateſmen Lawyers as Phyſitians.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: An Art familiar in the Roman State,
As ancient too as the firſt Monarchy.
O I could tell you Lawes worth millions to us,
By faire intrapping of the wealthy Clergy.

sp.speaker: ;Mal.
sp.l: Have you no model to inſnare a Prince?

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Henry the third, though wiſe and valiant,
Was caught in a ſtrong line knit by himſelfe,
Here ith mad Parliament,

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: As how?

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Twelve Peers
Under pretence of evil Officers
And grand abuſes, were ſelected out,
Strengthen'd with Lawes to prune Prerogatives,
To tutour and reform the State; to ſize
The Kings expence, and to appoint him Servants,
Both menial and forinſecal.

sp.speaker: Mal
sp.l: I'ſt poſſible The King ſhould ſeale to this?

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: O Poverty,
She to Obedience is the Lay-mother.
As ſome ſay Ignorance is the Clarklike,
Betwixt Superiours and Inferiours,
Look either way, this rule is mutual,
The poorer muſt be ſervant to the richer.
Henry brought low with various Action
Could not ſubſiſt without their ſubſidies.
Keep thy Prince poor, then thou ſhalt rule thy Ruler,
And ſubject thy Commander.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: This we try'd To faſten on Prudentius: but he
Too wiſe, too frugal was. Now Fancie
Through giddineſſe of minde, and vaſt expence,
Will prove leſſe wary and more prodigal.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Let ſome inſnareing Law be once propos'd, Fancie will yeild, not ponder.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Well, think you;
Ile ſpeak and ſpeed. O 'tis the praiſe of hate
To practiſe ruine and pretend the State.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: But Sir, I truſt upon your furtherance
About impropriations.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: You Ile remember
Firſt, or my ſelfe I ever ſhall forget.

div.head: SCENA III.
div.stage: Enter Fancie in a Cydaris, Concupiſcence, Fuga, Hilario before them.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: The Cydaris well fits me; now muſt I

〈◊〉
•• er this Perſian Crown with mutual fitneſſe.
What thing was proper to the Perſian Kings,
Say Memor.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Perſian Kings did wed their Siſters.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: Though in my Perſon thus I cannot wed,
Ile licence others. You Hilario
May, if you pleaſe, enjoy your lively Siſter
Concupiſcence.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.l: I thank your Majeſty
Both that I may, and may not; for to me
Nothing ſo pleaſing is as Liberty.
I would not be bound to that neither, though I love it beſt;
If I were, I ſhould long for the priſon.
Bind me to be rich, I ſhall play at Duckes and Drakes with peices;
Bind me to my good behaviour, I ſhall feele an itching deſire to beate the Juſtice.
O what a Prentiſe ſhould I make! I ſhould run away no oftner then I came in fight
Of the threſhold. And moſt of the Paſſions,
I think, have a ſpice of this humor.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: But can no bond pleaſe you like Liberty?

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.l: Neither bond of Matrimony, nor bond of friendſhip,
Nor bond of Uſury, nor bond of iniquity;
I rejoyce in the preſent, I deſire nothing, and therefore would be tied to nothing.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: Concupiſcence your Siſter's of another minde.

sp.speaker: Conc.
sp.l: I could well indure to be bound, ſo I might be looſe too.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: The Theme which I propos'd was Royalty,
No leſſe then Perſian. Then Concupiſcence,
How iſt we are ſo thinly waited on,
By Femal Paſſions? are there no more women
Of Paſſion kind?

sp.speaker: Conc.
sp.l: Of Paſſionate enough.
But to ſay Truth, the Femal Paſſions
As ſoon as they are born, turn all to ſins
And they are all my Children.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Then have you
More Daughters far then Danaus, or Margaret
Counteſſe of Henneberg: whereof one did equal
The weekes, and th' other the dayes of the year
With numerous iſſue.

sp.speaker: Conc.
sp.l: I have more by thouſands.
I'm as Fruitful and quick of Delivery
As any Uermin, ſpreading as Potatoes;
My race ruas o're the World.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: Or what age are they?

sp.speaker: Conc.
sp.l: As old as my ſelfe very neere.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Then you
Continued a maide no longer then Quartilla.

sp.speaker: Conc.
sp.l: O never at all that I can remember.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: You beare your age exceeding well.

sp.speaker: Conc.
sp.l: I hope
I ſhall be young forever; I have the vertue
Of making old folkes young by touching them.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: Are none of thoſe your Children ripe and handſome
And fit for our attendance?

sp.speaker: Conc.
sp.l: Pride my Eldeſt
She is the likelieſt.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: Let her be admitted.

sp.speaker: Conc.
sp.l: She's now i'th Spaniſh Court; but when ſhe comes—

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.l: Then the Court and her Mother will teach her to fall both wayes,
Forward and Backward.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: Till ſhe return, is't not in Fancie's power
To change a Sex, and make ſome Paſſion Female?

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: The like hath been; I have heard of a Femal
By meer force of Fancy turn'd Male. So Iphis
A Maide, in love with a Maide, was tranſform'd
Juſt on the marriage Eve. Tireſias
Was Male and Femal annually by turns;
Some Hermaphrodites have been both at once.

sp.speaker: Conc.
sp.l: Wud I could live and turn Hermaphrodite.

sp.speaker: Fug.
sp.l: Wud I could live and be of neither Sex.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: What think ye of transforming Amorous?

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.l: He's undone then: he cannot ſhew his legs, nor uſe his Poſtures
Nor enjoy his Idol Morphe.
No, change Sir Timerous,
He's as fearful as a Hare, and may be as changable:
He hath many Symbolical conditions of womanhood already:
He is Femal in every part but one, and half Femal in his cloathes
Give me but an Inch of Ribband from Fuga,
and I'le undertake to preſent him
The Lady Timida.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: Give him one of your changable Fancie's,
Thus firſt our ſelves muſt whet our own Invention;
Elſe others will not ſtir. Men do not ſtrive
Methinkes to pleaſe me as they ought to do.
No other rarities theſe many Ages
But Powder, Printing, Seaman Card, and Watches?
So much vain dotage for the fond Elixir?
Why are not yet my Chriſtals malleable,
To make our Gold no Gold, and foile the Di'mond?
Why want I Inſtruments to meaſure out
The Year, the Day, the Houre, without the help
Of Sun, or turning of theſe tedious wheeles?
Nothing to carry me but Barges, Coaches?
Sedans, and Litters? through the Aire I'd paſſe
By ſome new waftage▪ I muſt have my houſe
Convey'd by wheeles and ſailes and plummers hung
In ſome deep pit, deep as the way is diſtant,
To hurry me, my Family, and it,
Whether I pleaſe. Ile travel like the Snaile,
With all my houſe; but ſwifter then the Faulcon.

sp.speaker: Fug.
sp.l: Rare Lady!

sp.speaker: Conc.
sp.l: Raviſhing Inventions!

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: Why have not I not my Beds ſtuffd all with wind,
Baths fill'd with Maydew, Flowers preſerv'd till winter,
As well as Snow till Summer: choiſeſt Fruits
Growing and ripe in midſt of January?
Why have not I Ponds running through my Cellars,
For Bottles and for Fiſh call'd by their names?
Why not in drough an Artificial rain,
Scattered by ſpowtes, to cheer my Paradiſe?

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: I wiſh you had theſe things; I nere ſaw ſuch.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: Cheape I can have Aeolian bellowes made
Within the Bowles of Andirons, where the water
Shall blow the fire by which 'tis rarified.
I will have Vaults which ſhall convey my whiſpers
In ſteed of Embaſies to forreign Nations;
Places for Ecchoes to pronounce a ſpeech,
Or give a Suffrage like a multitude:
Conſorts well play'd by water; Pictures taught
By ſecret Organs both to move and ſpeak:
We ſpend our ſelves too much upon the Taylour;
I rather would new mold new faſhion Nature.

div.head: SCENA IIII.
div.stage: Enter Amorous and Liveby one way, Malevolo another way. After a while a Shew.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Pleaſes your Highneſſe to behold a Shew,
Wherein ſome Paſſions are diſplay'd by Dreams
How they affected are by Day.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: Ile ſee it.
What means that whiſper?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Tis an honeſt project
Thought on by Memor, out of love to Churches,
To buy back ſaleable impropriations
With charitable money. Doth it pleaſe you?

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: This task was fitter for Prudentius
Then Senſe or Paſſion. This although I grant,
Yet take it with condition. Memor knows
Conveyance old and new, the Right and Wrong.
In things not ſacred he may uſe his cunning,
In this he muſt be juſt. To you I ſay,
It was not ſeaſonable to move this buſineſs
When Shewes were comming.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: This your ſelfe did move
By asking.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Now.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Then make you here a Law,
That none theſe three dayes ſhall prefer a Sute
Or motion under forfeiture of life.
Me you ſhall finde content; I'm no Troubler.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: This trap is laid full right.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Stay, ſtay great Queen.
This Law will ſeale my mouth, and tie your hands,
And ſtop the neceſſary ſpeed of buſineſſe,
Whereby your Crown may be diſſolv'd.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: Away,
Away Malevolo.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: My ſnare for Liveby
Is brok, but violence ſhall it ſupply.
You Memor have your wiſh.

div.p:
Morpheus in a Cloud-coloured Caſsock with a wreath of Poppies and a Caduceus from a black Cell. Then at his call, ſix ſleeping Perſons in their night caps half down their Faces, and in their waſtcoates, repreſenting in their clothes downwards Memor,
Malevolo, Irato, Timerous, Hilario, Deſperato. Morpheus ſhakes his Caduceus over them ſeverally as they ſtand in Couples. Being mov'd they fall ſucceſſively into their proper geſtures, and laſtly all dance together in thoſe geſtures.

sp.speaker: More.
sp.l: I Morpheus King of Dreames, whoſe might
Can equal Fanci's in the night,
Have caus'd the night ſix dreames to ſend:
As I appointed they attend
sp.stage: They enter from a black Cave.
sp.l: Now Memor turn thy Books and prate,
Plead with thy hands and fees then take.
Shrug, ſcratch, Malevolo, and grin,
Graſp thy foule heart and feel thy ſin.
Irato, bend thy fiſt and draw,
Offer to thruſt, keep fear in aw.
Shak Timerous, offer to fly,
Begin to ſink, offer to die.
Hilario clap thy hands and laugh,
Skip, leap, and turn, offer to quaff.
Deſpaire ſtart, ſtand, and cruſh thy throat,
Then ſtab thy breaſt and groan death's note.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: Whoſe labour was this ſport?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Livebys invention and my contriving.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: For this I'le ſend you to your deareſt Morphe.
Goe at what hour you pleaſe, and ſay I want
Her company at Court. You, Hope, for this,
And for preventing that pernicious Law,
Ask what you will.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Grant the Monopoly
Of Watches, or of Beavers. Fan take them both;
And ask again.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: When woodlands ſhall be turn'd
To other uſe, grant me a twelfth as forfeit.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: Be it confirm'd▪

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: I was about to ask
The Patronage of Churches in Sea-towns;
Where popular choice maintains a Faction
Brought in with Merchandize from forreign parts.
But that were better taken to the Crown.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: Take what thou wilt. Thou
begſt to give us ſhare.
None can pleaſe all, the beſt the better fare.

div.head: SCENA. V.
div.stage: The Scene turns to feilds, walkes & ſcattered houſes. Enter Hilario, and then Sir Timerous with Fuga's ribband.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: By this way Sir Timerous ſhould come; whom I as ſent from his wrong'd Lady Fuga have engag'd in a quarrel againſt Audax. And yonder comes the pittiful Earthquake moſt lovingly trembling.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: What ſhould I do here? ſome deſperate knave or other, Deſperato himſelf (it may be) hath rob'd me of my beſt weapon. I thought not to have fought with ſteele, but with Gold; and to have brought this needy Captain to an honourable ſubmiſſion by dint of Caſh. What diſaſters have I? That unreaſonablly wicked, that divliſh two fac'd Cutter knew me too well: for when I drew this harmleſs blade, he look'd upon it as ſlightly as upon a riding wand; and bad me familiarly put up that, and draw my purſe. Certainly I have too much of the Mother; I am that which they call a Coward, and all the world knows it. Wherefore (O Ribband) I take it extream ſcurvily of Fuga, that ſhe being of the ſame temper her ſelfe, doth not conſider her temper in me.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Now this Craven ſtands as tickliſh on the point of running as a Bowle on the top of a ridg.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p:
Two ſteps further I'le move. I have been coming a quarter of a mile theſe two houres at leaſt; and yet I ſweat till
the very drops run a race; my ſhaking feaver is turn'd to a cold ſweat, and that's a true Prognoſtication of death.

Good night to all the world; for this is that fatal peice of ground which I ſhall anon-meaſure with my Carcaſſe. Never a Buſh nor Hole here? though it be call'd Champion ground I ſhall not fight: perhaps I ſhall make uſe of its plainneſſe, and give ground a mile or two; that ſhall be my way of fighting. For if I the Challenger ſtand ſtill on my guard, it will not ſtand with mine honour: And then while I keep my backſword point ſtill in his face (I have ſeen the play at cudgells) he will wheele about me, and falſifying a blow at the head will ſtrike me juſt on the legs where my heart lies. Then ſhall I be quite ſpoiled for running away; which I think I had beſt do preſently, for I hear him coming. O—

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Now I ſee Sir Tim, thou art a Lad of mettle.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Mettle? I proteſt Sir I had rather drink this cold iron fil'd ſmall to duſt and be a Lad of mettle ſo, then to thruſt it whole into any mans fleſh whatſoever; much leſſe into my Enemies. You ſee then what power Love hath, and how Fuga is beholding to me.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Moſt dreadfully.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Is not the time yet paſt? I think I may retire with honour, and ſay he durſt not meet me.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: It wants yet halfe an hour. If you hold not out your time, then he'l aſſault you openly in Court, and make your ſhame publick, which otherwiſe will be but private. Ile ſtand ſecretly by you, and if need require will ſtep in and part you.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Stand not far off I beſeech you for when I am kill'd I ſhall not be able to call.—O my heart!—the Gyant's coming—O—Hilario— Malevolo paſſes by.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.p: Saw you not here Irato?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: No believe me Sir; no I thank heaven. Hilario!—Now comes Audax. O—I have but a minute to live. Irato paſſes by.

sp.speaker: Ir.
sp.p: How now ſtinkerd, how does thy breech? ſawſt thou not here Malevolo?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: He paſt by in haſt; juſt now in haſt.—Well. Two Furies are paſt. Ile not wait for the third, go Love and Honour whither they will. Hilario!—I fear he hath left me. Ile raze my Fleſh with a ſlight cut, and ſweare I receiv'd that wound in fight. But now I think on't better, I have an iſſue under my left arme; Ile force that bigger till it bleed, and ſwear that into a wound. For ſure a freſh one would be far greater pain. Soft, I am loath to ſuffer ſo much, if I may chuſe Hilario?—

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: What a Champion are you? not dare to look a man in the face?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Sweet Hilario, I conſider thou haſt no Sword to help me: ſtretch thy wit, and invent ſome ſpeedy way, how I may eſcape with honour, and not fight?

sp.speaker: Hil
sp.p: You cannot poſſibly eſcape fighting.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Sweet Hilario do not kill me before hand with ſaying ſo.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Why then will you be rul'd by me?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: In any thing, any thing. Quickly for love of Life.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: I have promis'd to furniſh the Queen with a new Lady attendant.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Put on Womans apparel, you ſhall be ſhe; by name of Madam Timida.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Ha! Say on.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Then ſhall you be free, not onely from this quarrel, but from all future beatings and challenges.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Safe and ſound!

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Then ſhall you have perpetual acceſſe to Fuga, bully.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Safe and delicious!

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Then to ſteale her affection you may habit your ſelfe like her.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Safe and wiſe!

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Then as for you honour, who can upbraid you when you are no where to be ſound: twill be ſuppos'd by your ſweet friend, that you died in her quarrel, Audax if he himſelf talk will be dangerouſly queſtion'd.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: But will you be ſecret?

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: For mine own ſake, mine own ſake, Sir Tim.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Deareſt Hilario, thou art my preſerving Angel.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Make haſt, before you can new caſt your ſelfe Ile come to preſent you.
Poor ſnake, I delivered no Challeng; I onely frighted him to a more willing Metamorphoſis.

div.head: SCENA VI.
div.stage: Enter by him Concupiſcence in a Citizens habit.

sp.speaker: Conc.
sp.l: Hey ho for a husband; Two three, or more,
As many as I meet; 'tis fit, that we
Ladies Attendant ſhould be qualified
For three at leaſt.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.l: What ere the habit be, this is the Face
The Voice and language of Concupiſcence,
Why, how now Siſter, taking the Aire alone?

sp.speaker: Conc.
sp.l: A ſafe Conſcience never feares any man.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.l: I think thou fear'ſt not any, but lov'ſt all.
Such was thy wont; and haſt thou now a Conſcience?

sp.speaker: Conc.
sp.l: Be grave or ſilent, know I'm rectified.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.l: Pox on your train: by feigned honeſty
You ſeek to wooe me. I'le unvaile you ſtreight.
What think you of two husbands, three, or more,
As many as you meet?

sp.speaker: Conc.
sp.l: Why didſt thou hear me?

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.l: Ladies Attendant ſhould be qualified
For three at leaſt.

sp.speaker: Conc.
sp.l: That I ſpoke merrily.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.l: If thou hadſt ten, thou ſtill wouldſt cry more Hymens.

sp.speaker: Conc.
sp.l: If ſo you think, think on, I think ſo too.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.l: But when will all thy maidenheads be ſpent?
Tell me ſincerely, truly, and bodily.

sp.speaker: Conc.
sp.l: They come again like Teeth, I'm breeding now.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.l: Then are thy maidenheads like Hydra's heads,
Not to be tam'd but by a Hercules.
Who has the next?

sp.speaker: Conc.
sp.l: I am reſolv'd to part it
Betwixt a Courtier and a Citizen:
The Courtier has the maide, the Citizen
Shall have the head.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.l: Siſter, I cannot wed you,
You have too much complexion for my uſe:
But Ile provide you one ſhall bear the name
Of Husband.

sp.speaker: Conc.
sp.l: Let him be honeſt, quiet.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.l: Of you own garb, ſay he be Melancolico.
And ſo Ile rid my ſelfe of Fanci's march.

sp.speaker: Conc.
sp.l: I care but for his ſhadow having Servants.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.l: Farewell Carnality.

sp.speaker: Conc.
sp.l: Hilario thinks
He took me, when alas twas my intent
The Boy ſhould overheare, and ſo become
If not a Husband, ſuch an Officer.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: What's here? Concupiſcence?

sp.speaker: Conc.
sp.l: Nor ſtare, nor ſtartle;
As I hope to look ſaire, I'm nothing chang'd
In minde or body. No where, but in habit.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: And why in This?

sp.speaker: Conc.
sp.l: O for Variety.
Fancy permits all change. This dreſſe ſometimes
Pleaſes the Courtier better then his Ladies.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Is it but ſo? come then my Paphian drum,
I'le brace the cloſe.

sp.speaker: Conc.
sp.l: Soft Sir, you march too feircely.
I have a task which firſt you muſt perform;
I fear you will not do't; you do not love
me;
Promiſe me firſt; the task I can aſſure you,
Befitts your Valour, and will pay it ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Is it to kill the Queen, that thou mayſt reign?

sp.speaker: Conc.
sp.l: No, nor her maide; thou ſhalt but uſe her kindly.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Speak plain, be bold.

sp.speaker: Conc.
sp.l: Then thou ſhalt raviſh Fuga.
She twits me with my Servants, Favours, Lookes,
My Words, and ſcapes: in This you bear a ſhare.
If this to me bring ſhame, you are not free.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Is this your heavy task? no more but This?
Onely to raviſh? is not the work Reward?
Ile do't effectually; Her ſelfe ſhall thank me.

sp.speaker: Conc.
sp.l: But I'le outthank her far; Ile raviſh thee
With faſt embraces. Take this kiſſe in earneſt
Of future payment. Though I ſeeme a Veſtal,
To thee I'm Venus.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Venus, be ſecur'd.

sp.speaker: Conc.
sp.l: Then, when her fruit ſhall ſwell, and I ſtand ſimpring,
Turn'd to a ſeeming Saint, O how Ile triumph
In grave reproofe and holy Admonition!
This 'tis to be too chaſt.—here come the Stagemen.

div.head: SCENA VIII.
div.stage: Enter to her Malevolo, Irato, Memor.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Sir you and we were acted at the Court.
We looſers are made laughing-ſtocks, and ſport
For open Stages.

sp.speaker: Ir.
sp.l: Tell my Sword the Author;
That it my write his doome upon his fleſh.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: This Creature can informe us.
Who I pray
Were your late witwrights in the Maſque?

sp.speaker: Conc.
sp.l: Hope pend it,
My Father Amorous (without Offence)
Contriv'd the Shew.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: This trick Malevolo
Was chiefly meant to you, becauſe your pen
Hath ſcourg'd the Stage.

sp.speaker: Ir.
sp.l: However Lord Irato
Shall act a red Cataſtrophe on Liveby:

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Ile watch his haunt and hunt
him to his fall;
You Amorous too. This mirth of theirs at laſt
Shall cloſe their ſweetneſſe with an Aloed taſt.
Theſe once remov'd, who can be great but I;
Whoſe word ſhall ſway but mine? Then power is ſweet
When Rubs are made the ſtaires to mount our feet.

div.head: SCENA I.
div.stage: Enter Deſperato in a Phyſitians habit.

sp.speaker: Deſp.
sp.l: Whatever chang ſucceed, ſtill wretchedneſſe
My old inſeparable mate hangs on.
Therefore I ſeem ridiculous; my grief
Is others mirth; Malevolo ſayes I'm acted▪
Henceforth Ile finde new Company: ſince Fate
Barrs me from others happineſſe, Ile ſpread
My miſery to others; and Ile thrive
Meerely in ſpite, to make men miſerable.
This is my humour; 'tis begun already.
The Gold I took from Timerous, if queſtion'd,
I can defend; I took it in my humour;
And that's good law; I took it in a humour
Moſt deſperatly bent; and it hath made me
Such as men ſee, an able man for miſcheif;
Clad me in th' outſide of a myſtery,
Furniſh'd my ſhelves with Pots, with Boxes, Names,
Slight Medicines, and ſtrong Poyſons. Time hath been,
When I in War ſerv'd Death a Prentiſhip;
There learn'd to open Veynes, to lance and kill;
Now I am free o'th Trade; a Soldier then,
Phyſitian now; Ile do the ſelfe ſame work,
But now more Artificially.—

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: —The godly
〈◊〉 in diſtreſſe; the wicked, that uſurp
The Childrens right, do here grow fat and proſper:
Wherefore I thought of drowning. Verily
•• uleſſe that Conſcientious Lawyer,
Good Memor, from rebought Impropriations,
Had thus deducted and diſtributed
The better part to us oppreſſed Brethren,
Affliction ſome, and ſome Devotion
Had brought me to deſpaire. Now Ile not ſee him.

sp.speaker: Deſp.
sp.l: Methinkes dejected Melancholico
Should prove fit Timber for my fatal work.
What, Melancholico? not know your friend,
Whoſe medci'nal skill cures Body, Minde, and State?
Truſt thou art not over lucky; art?
Do'ſt feel no miſery?
I thought ere this ſhould have had thy cuſtome.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Verily
My ſickneſſe could but little cure your purſe.

sp.speaker: Deſp.
sp.l: It might have brought me practiſe howſoever,
And that's the onely Fee of new profeſſours.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: But are you then indeed a true profeſſour,
And one of Us? Sooth I profeſſe ſincerity,

sp.speaker: Deſp.
sp.l: Hath not the ſame which caus'd ſincerity,
Caus'd a foule ſpleen? no Hypocondrick Vapours?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: For that a godly Lawyer gave me phyſick:

sp.speaker: Deſp.
sp.l: Then take it next from a Divine.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: That Lawyer
Firſt took it from Divines, then gave it me.
And I can give you counſel to your phyſick:
You have a faire advantage in mens ſickneſſe
To prick the Conſcience, and to let them know,
Their onely way is to releive the Breren,
And 〈◊〉 their ſtock of holy uſury
For new Plantations. You ſhall have a ſhare.

sp.speaker: Deſp.
sp.l: This is a verier rogue then I my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: And what I pray mov'd you to turn Phyſitian?

sp.speaker: Deſp.
sp.l: Want ſet me on, a booty ſet me up.
Now let me know of mutual curteſie,
What was your Dos?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: 'Twill buy all yours; 'twas Gold.

sp.speaker: Deſp.
sp.l: Why then, thou'ſt run unto preſumption,
Not to deſpaire. I heare you are to marry;
Which if thou doſt, then thou wilt come to me,
For Ratsbane, Hensbane, ſome ſuch wholſome banes,
To cure thy bands of Matrimony.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Hence.

div.head: SCENA III.
div.stage: Enter to him Hilario and Concupiſcence.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.l: Friend Melancholico,
How is't? Siſter, ſtand by a while. Methinks
Upon a ſudden you are grown brisk and cheereful,
Fit company for me, nay for a wife.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: You'l never leave your waggery and jeaſting.
" You call'd Peculiars rags of Popery.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.l: Sometimes you are too ſad and ſolitary:
Is this jeaſting? and ſolitarineſſe
Requires due Recreation; Is this jeaſting?
And Recreation much conſiſteth in
The yoak of a meet helper; you may call
This jeaſting too; but is't not ſport in earneſt?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: The Saints allow no ſport.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.l: Then love in earneſt.
You know you cannot well converſe with men;
Your lookes are indiſpos'd, your language ſparing,
Your manners different. But to a woman
A long Parentheſis of buſi'd ſilence
Does paſſing well. Then in her company
You have a world, and none to contradict.
And in her Ear you may reform the Church,
Or purg the State, as ſafe, as if you ſpake
Ʋnto the Aire or whiſper'd to your ſelfe,
For ſo ſhe is. Think on a wife.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: No wife.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.l: Then on a ſpouſe.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Now you ſay ſomewhat.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.l: Now.
He'l marry words not ſubſtance. The word whore
Would have ſpoil'd all. This blockhead ſuites with me
As froſt with fire. But for your ſake Ile thaw him.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Have you not injur'd that fair promiſing Siſter
By leaving her alone?

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.l: She meditates.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: She walketh gravely, turns her eye devoutly.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.l: The white's pure, the black as full of Adultery
As thou art of Hypocriſie; ſhe harbours
A good conceit of you. Shall ſhe concive Further?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: If that her name be right.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.l: She was Concupiſcence, now call'd Temperance Siſter
This is your Husband whom I ſo commended.

sp.speaker: Conc.
sp.l: I chuſe not for my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Siſter and Spouſe,
If ſo you pleaſe, our hands ſha'l us unite
Marches are made in Heaven; few words ſuffice
The Night conſummates. As for other rites
