I hold them ſuperſtitious Ceremonies.
I had forgot her Portion.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.l: She's a widow,
He ſhew you her Eſtate.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: He firſt retire
And claſp her hand in zeale.

sp.speaker: Conc.
sp.l: my Lord and Bridegroome.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.l: The Divel and his Dam you are. Come Brother.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Once more. I like your meditation,
But do not ſpend your ſelfe therewith too much.

sp.speaker: Conc.
sp.l: Now I am double ſhelter'd in my hear,
With name of Husband, and this formal guiſe.

sp.speaker: Conc.
sp.l: Now welcome Servant; have you won the Fort?

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Hell take her, ſhe's a man.

sp.speaker: Conc.
sp.l: A man?

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Juſt ſo I found, ſcarce left him ſo.

sp.speaker: Conc.
sp.l: O you miſtooke. Sir Timerous is transform'd to wait at Court:
Twas Phanci's own device. O I could laugh.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: I made him ſo much woman as to cry;
" Elſe I had made him woman with my Sword.

sp.speaker: Conc.
sp.l: Alas poor Timida.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: The thing ſo trembled,
No leafe nor ague like him.

sp.speaker: Conc.
sp.l: Ha ha ha.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Did you intend to put this trick upon me?

sp.speaker: Conc.
sp.l: No by the kiſſes which ſhall ſatisfie
Thy height forthwith, and pay thy errour full.
Beſides I'm ſatisfied with this miſtake
As well as with the right. Aſperſion
Shall blot the name of Fuga full as much.

div.head: SCENA V.
div.stage: Enter to them Sir Tim. as Timida. After a while Fuga, alike dreſs'd.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: What's this? the He or She?

sp.speaker: Conc.
sp.l: No matter which.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: If it be ſhe, I'le raviſh her; if he,
Then thou ſhalt do't.

sp.speaker: Conc.
sp.l: Neither▪ tis done enough.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Tim hath a fine time on't.

sp.speaker: Conc.
sp.l: Come, you have a better.—

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Is this to be a woman? O I could teare,
As timerous as I am, my lawnes to rags,
And ſcratch my face, and ſtick my heart with pins,
Or ſtreight turn valiant. Wud my Fuga knew,
What ſhe hath ſcap'd through me.
And here ſhe comes.
O Fuga, female habit and ſtrang ſufferings
Have lent me tongue enough. Now I can ſpeake;
And boldly ſay I have deſerved your love.

sp.speaker: Fug.
sp.l: Wherein Sir Lady?

sp.speaker: I Tim.
sp.l: Now in this your habit ſav'd you from a hideous raviſhing. Audax with whom I ſhould have fought, came on me
With love more rude then rage, blaſted my face
With breath like brimſtone, turn'd my limbs like twigs;
I live by miracle.

sp.speaker: Fug.
sp.l: You came too neere
Uuto a Sex from which you ſhould keep further.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Shall I not then be neer and dear unto you?

sp.speaker: Fug.
sp.l: Experience tells you what a boyſtrous thing
Tis to be ruffled by a man.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Still ſo? Why I have been a woman for thy ſake;
I hear within theſe weedes a minde as tender,
White skin, blew veines, and armes as ſoft as thine.

sp.speaker: Fug.
sp.l: But ſtill you are a man, and I ſtill Fuga.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Nothing can merit love from peviſhneſſe.
What ſhall I do? I'le ſtreight turn man again,
And ſuffer for my ſelfe. Farewel coy woman,
Ungrateful, and unwiſe. My raviſhment
Is fairely paſt, but yours may be the next.
How ere when I appear my ſelfe, the noiſe
Of what is paſt will light upon your name.
I bore the loathſome ſuffering for thee,
Now ſhalt thou bear the foule reproach for me.

sp.speaker: Fug.
sp.l: Much I was overſeen, too much extreamely;
I could run after him; but if he turn
I ſhall run back again. O I am loſt;
My Honour, Safety, and perhaps ſome liking,
All theſe are loſt, with theſe I'm loſt, loſt Fuga.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: This change of State gaines me ſmall perfect pleaſure.
Meer meditation on Morphe's beauty
Will not ſuffice. Come Fuga, ſince thy Ocean
Cannot be miniſh'd by ſome drops, give freely
What Audax forc'd.

sp.speaker: Fug.
sp.l: That I am miſerable
Is't not enough, unleſſe I bear more burdens
Of common ſcorn, or (which is worſe) true ſtayning?
Good Sir, of all the Paſſions you are gentleſt;
Though you eſteem me light, which I am not,
Yet take ſome weight unto your ſelfe. Conſider
That after this you cannot worthy be
Of Morphe, never woe with confidence.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Thus ſtill a Female Sermon puts me by,
And I gain nothing by my Liberty.
Once more I ask.

sp.speaker: Fug.
sp.l: Once was too much before.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Once more.

sp.speaker: Fug.
sp.l: Firſt kill me.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Then to make you quick
Is paſt my cunning.

div.head: SCENA VII.
div.stage: Enter Hilario, Concupiſcence, after a while Melancholico.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.l: Joy to you Madam Fuga, you know why.

sp.speaker: Conc.
sp.l: If I could give you Joy of what I loath,
And you delight in, this if I could do
Without a ſin, I would.

sp.speaker: Fug.
sp.l: Is falſe report
Worſe then true guilt? how i'ſt this filthy Strumpet
Lookes like a Saint, and I as foule as hell?

sp.speaker: Conc.
sp.l: Lady, an Eye refin'd ſees more then dull ones,
And Holineſſe far clearer then Uncleaneſs.
I wonder what looſe words and actions
Have paſs'd from you, to give incouragment
To the kind raviſher; for I have heard
None can be raviſh'd without ſome conſent.
Be humbled, know you fault, live chaſter Lady.

sp.speaker: Fug.
sp.l: Sure I ſhould think I'm guilty.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Out upon thee.
Fie Temperance, what here? wilt thou have Eggs
And rotten Oranges flung at thee too?
What can you chuſe no other company
But this lewde, crack'd abominable peice?

sp.speaker: Conc.
sp.l: You ſee your company is ſcandalous,
I muſt take leave.

sp.speaker: Fug.
sp.l: If there be any power
To ſee and judge, I challeng his aſſiſtance.
What have I done, unleſſe too ſtedfaſt coyneſſe
Be now accounted looſeneſſe? what's my Crime,
That ſuch a general ſtorme of loude diſgrace
Conſpires to bear down Innocence? Hold heart,
Hold my weake ſpirits: for if this continue
I ſhall grow deſperate.—

sp.speaker: Fug.
sp.l: —Pitty me Father,
My name is ſtain'd beyond all patience.
Sir Timerous having fooliſhly put on
My ſhape; in ſtead of me was rudely raviſh'd
By bluſtring Audax. The reproach is mine.
You know a darkſome cloud can much obſcure
The face of water though as pure as Chriſtal.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Audax ſhall rue this baſe attempt, whoſe ſhadow
Blots your opinion, and portends more danger
Unto your Perſon. Caſt your cares on me.

sp.speaker: Fug.
sp.l: I may communicate, not caſt them off.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: I thought to uſe him in a bold deſign
Gainſt Liveby, and I will; 'tis dangerous
Unto himſelfe. If combat raine one,
Vengeance perſues the other: thus Ile make
The vanquiſh'd and the victor both my prey,
And whilſt they fight, my ſelfe ſhall win the day.

div.head: SCENA IX.
div.stage: Enter by him Irato and Audax quarreling.

sp.speaker: Ir.
sp.l: What, you that Office? know your turn; give place
Firſt to your betters. You be General?

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Yes I. And know, that whilſt I hold a Sword
To prove my worth, the Sun beholds none better.
Neither your Lordſhip nor Controwlerſhip
Can daſtard me.

sp.speaker: Ir.
sp.l: But I ſhall teach you diſtance.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Make me draw back one inch, and gain this place,
Then thou gain'ſt That. Be calmer good Irato.

sp.speaker: Ir.
sp.l: Unwing the Lightning, ſtop Araxes floods,
Then mayeſt thou ſtop my wrath, and guard thy ſelfe
Againſt my ſtroke.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Hold, hold; what means this Fury?
May I be Umpire in your difference?

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Know it you may; this feirce and haughty Lord
Croſſes my aime, and ſtands Competitour
For what he underſtands not, to be General.

sp.speaker: Ir.
sp.l: Not underſtand? give way Malevolo.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: You may be fit to quarrel in a Tavern,
But not to lead an Army.

sp.speaker: Ir.
sp.l: Give me ſcope;
Unleſſe thou wouldſt be broach'd on the ſame blade,
And coupled plung in Styx; open the way.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Why would you ſeek this Office?

sp.speaker: Ir.
sp.l: Cauſe I ſcorn
That any man ſhould be prefer'd before me.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: And why would you?

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Becauſe I can do ſervice;
And would gain honour, equal unto His.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: There's yet no Army levi'd, there's no cauſe,
But doubtful Rumour.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: When there is, Ile lead it.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Yes, both alike; while you contend for ſhadows, Liveby will bear the ſubſtance from you both.
Rid him, then you may talk.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: What ſayes Irato?

sp.speaker: Ir.
sp.l: Agreed.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Then you ſhall take him now in th' Evening,
Comming from Intellectus: there's his haunt,—
Now try your fury on a third; for I
Stanch'd not this combat out of love, but hate,
To turn them hot, and mad, on Liveby's blood;
That done, meet ſeas again; I'le be no Iſthmus;
But ſpur their heat, and clap them on the ſhoulder.
For I my ſelfe firſt rais'd this bruite of war,
For fuel of ſome new commotion;
Which luckily takes fire betwixt theſe two.

div.head: SCENA X.
div.stage: Enter by him Amorous and Muſitian. Then Morphe.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Now Amorous; you ſit in Fortunes lap,
Your Miſtreſſe ſits in yours; you ſpend your dayes
In Honour, and Delight.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: I ſhall the more,
If with your liking.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Mine? I am your Theme
For mirth at Court; one of your Hobby-horſes: And glad of ſuch perferment; but I'le daſh
And poyſon your ſweet delicates.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l:
Your hate (Ex. Mal.
Shall not break off my Scene of Love.
Stand there,
And ſend thy notes like ſhafts through Morphe's Eare.
Sweet Morphe lend a feeling eare
To the ſoft ſtraines wherein I bear
My ſoul, and ſigh it out to thee
Compos'd of ſweeter harmony;
With one kind word or ſmile
Reprive the man a while,
Who life doth crave
Thy print to ſave,
And feares to make his breaſt, thy Pictures grave.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: (Above) Why do you trouble both your ſelfe and me,
With ſuch fond circumſtance of open wooing?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: I'm glad at any rate to hear your voice,
Though ſent in chiding. But my deareſt Morphe,
I have a buſineſſe to you from the Queen,
Beſides mine own.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: This you pretend to wrong me.
Though I be loyal, yet my loyalty
Ought not to make me Traytor to my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: If I be falſe or any way immodeſt,
Accuſe and ſhun me.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Shall I then believe you?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Adde to that curſe a greater if you can,
And may it fall upon me.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Well, I come.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Now having liberty to act my will,
No Law but this vain curſe to hold me in,
How ſhall I bear my ſelf?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: What wills the Queen?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: She calls you to her company at Court.
She wants your privacy; you likewiſe want
Her publick preſence: O you wrong your beauty
By ſhutting ſuch a Jewel from the gaze
Of ſolemne adoration.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Pray excuſe me;
If I have beauty, let me keep it well.
The various Faſhions, and new Fancies there,
In the opinion of us plainer beauties,
Do but Sophiſticate the Elements
Of native Colour, and diſtort the lines
Of proper figure. What ſhould I do there?
Say I am ſickly, as this newes hath made me.
Farewell Sir Amorous.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Nay, tis not modeſty
But blunt ſtupidity to part ſo ſoon.
May I not walk and take you by the arme,
And paſſe a faire diſcourſe? what hurt in This?
May I not feed my ſpirits with the aire
That fans your cheekes? lighten mine eye from yours?
Is this immodeſt?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Hark.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: 'Tis the claſh of weapons.

div.head: SCENA. XI.
div.stage: Enter Live by hope perſued by Audax and Irato They ſpeed him and paſs along.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Help Amorous, help.—O—it comes too late.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Ignoble Swords, and bloody butcherers!
Who would believe that two ſuch Hercules
Should joyn againſt a ſingle Hylas thus.
It was not manly.—Morphe—O my life!
This hideous ſight hath ſtruck her gentle ſpirits
With frighted numneſſe. Water, ſpirits, help.—
Out ſtrip the wind, fly for a Phyſitian.—
I'le rub her Temples, rouze her by the name
Which ſhe beſt knows: Morphe.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: O!

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Life there appears;
Is there none here? how ſhould I ſave them both?
Help there, 'tis but a Sowne. I feele ſome breath.
I'le bear her hence.—O that my armes might claſp
Her living thus, and willing.—

sp.speaker: Int.
sp.l: —Hence did thrill
That peircing noiſe. What's here? ſee falſe mine eyes!
Poor Liveby ſlaine? then for thy Soveraignes favour
Thou diedſt a Martyr.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: O, Intellectus help.

sp.speaker: Int.
sp.l: He ſpeaks; ther's hope of life. If Art can ſave
A thrid ſo mangled, thus Ile bear thee to't.
Although my breaſt have us'd to bear it's burden
Within, and not without.—

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: (above)—Looke carefully
Unto your Lady. Let the Phyſitan
Firſt ſpeak with me.—Now to my ſecond loade.—
What? vaniſh'd? I have heard of walking ghoſts,
Never of walking carcaſſes. Then ſurely
The Murderers have drag'd him hence. His blood
Will riſe upon their cheekes; and it ſhall ſpeak
Lowd on my Tongue.—

div.head: SCENA XIII.
div.stage: Enter by him Fancie in a Turbant, Fuga, after a while Muſitian, Deſperato.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: —Now in my Turkiſh Turbant
I walk to find Sir Amorous in his heaven.
Be not ſo deeply diſcontented Fuga.

sp.speaker: Fug.
sp.l: Unleſſe you cleare me openly, I die.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: I finde you Amorous ſomewhat neare your Center.
Your Morphe fitteſt is to be a Queen.
I go to waite on her, and fetch her home
With me.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Sweet Soul (that's all ſhe is by this)
I cannot tell you in what world ſhe is,
Nor where I am my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: And why?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: She's dying,
Frighted with ſuch a diſmal accident,
That when I tell it, I much fear your highneſſe
Will be as weak as ſhe.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: Speak, I am arm'd.
Where's Livebyhope?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: The ſame I faine would know:
Laſt when I ſaw him, he was laid for dead.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: How dead?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Tis ſo. Juſt now: not far from hence,
Two bloody Villaines, Audax and Irato,
Perſued and ſped him with two mortal wounds.
I ran to help; Morphe fell in a Sownd;
I bore her hence; mean while his Corps were gone.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: I am perplext beyond my power of bearing.
My arme is lopt, my Kingdom is all tumult▪
The Paſſions taking vantage of my Law,
Follow their humours to their mutual ruine;
sp.stage: Enter Mus. with Deſp. Am. ſeems to talk with him.
sp.l: And run like Veſſels till they quite run out.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Mix ſome ingredient to excite her Love.
Doctor, thou ſhalt be rich,

sp.speaker: Deſp.
sp.l: I'le fit you all.
Morphe for phyſick ſends, Malevolo
Hath purchas'd me long ſince to give her poyſon;
Sir Amorous buyes a Love-pill: I my ſelfe,
Ev'n I, that will be Maſter in concluſion,
Intend to mix them all: then fight confuſion.

div.head: SCENA XIIII.
div.stage: Enter to them Audax and Irato, at length Malevolo ſecretly.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Pleaſes your highneſſe to decide by choice,
Or leave it to our Swords, who ſhall be General?

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: Then I am bound to honour one of them
For their good ſervice. Bloodhounds, have ye murder'd
One worth you both? and dare to ask reward
Of me? of me ſo wrong'd? So both will joine
In mutual revenge, and fall together,
Fight for't.

sp.speaker: Ir.
sp.l: Fond Queen, what if our rage proceed,
To hew Sir Amorous for telling this,
You for diſtaſting? all will be but humour.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Then give us not occaſion to proceed.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: Proceed, I pray you, do. Lo, here's my breaſt.
Tent it; to finde the greife which I conceive
For Livebys Death, and your more horrid Lives.
What, have ye ſurfeited with blood? good Amorous,
Do't thou, do't ſtreight: what theſe refuſe as Rebels,
Do as a Friend. Kill me, but kill me gently,
With ſome ſad ſtraine under this ſpreading Oake.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: I hope 'twill eaſe not kill you.
Sing of Venus.

lg.l: Once Venus cheekes that ſham'd the morn
Her lipps, that Winter had out born,
Her heat grew cold, her nectar dry.
No juyce ſhe had but in her eye,
The wonted fire and flames to mortifie.
When was this ſo diſmal ſight?

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: The ſame which turn'd her beauty, turns my Fancy,
Alas poor Liveby.—What dee mean to thruſt?
Fie what a preſſe is here? ſtand off; for I
Am but a Cloud: your Elbowes peirce me through;
Your hot and angry breaths will ſtreight diſſolve me.
And I ſhall crack into a ſhowre of Teares.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Alas ſhe's crak'd indeed, the
Queen's diſtemper'd.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: Do you not ſee, and hear a Lamb there bleating?
Pray kill him not, he bears the head of Liveby.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: In a mad world what uſe of place? what buſineſſe?

sp.speaker: Ir.
sp.l: Now had I any anger left, I'd ſhred
That Fidler into Atomes.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: O, I'm ſtruck
(Plague on Malevolo that fets us on!)
I'm ſtruck at heart with leaden heavineſſe!

sp.speaker: Ir.
sp.l: I feele my veines now curdled; what ſucceſſe
But Horror of this Fact?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: I ſee and hear
Enough to grate me. O that plotts well laid
Should thus be daſh'd and foyld.—

div.head: SCENA XV.
div.stage: Enter Melancholico with a Petition, after him Sir Timerous in mans habit.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: —That naughty Boy Hilario hath match'd me to the Divel.
Hell flames are in her; ſhe hath ſtuck a brand
" Into my bones; I ſue for juſt divorcement.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Did not you ſnuffle till you match'd my Daughter?
Peace, or you'l ſhame your ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: A pretty Picture, Here's Day and Night united in one peice;
Look here a Swan, look there a foule black Raven.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Juſtice great Queen againſt a multitude.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: That's hard to be obtain'd.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l:
Againſt Irato,
Tilario, Deſperato, Audax:
Some beat, ſome cheate, ſome rob, ſome raviſh me.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: What ſaiſt? Go on and ſtill that howling kennel.
I know you well, for all you are a Torteſſe,
And have liv'd like a frog in diverſe Elements.
Of what Gender are you? Go learn of Protens
How to do tricks. If you be dull and blockiſh,
You muſt be beaten. Come to me for Juſtice?
Judge one another, or get you all to Liveby.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: He's in his grave.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: And therefore get ye to him.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: No doing's here: I'm gone.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: And I: but whither?

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: No Amorous, Liveby ſleeps, but Morphe's dead.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Heaven help you Lady.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: But I can ſoon reſtore her.
" Take you the ſent of a Travellers toes,
" The ſneeze of a Sleeper freſh from his noſe;
" The fat of a Frier well fed with faſting,
" The lean of a Drunkard conſum'd with taſting;
" The juyce of a Lemmon tha's civil at ſeaſons,
" Twelve dancing Capers, ten lunatick Reaſons;
" Two dying notes of an ancient Swan,
" Three Sighes a thouſand years kept if you can:
" Some ſcrapings of Giges his Ring may paſſe,
" With the skin of a Shadow caught in a glaſſe;
" Six peny worth of Thoughts untold,
" The jelly of a Star before it be cold;
" One ounce of Courtſhip from a country-Daughter,
" A grain of Wit, and a quart of Laughter.
" Boyle theſe on the Fire of Zeal or of Luſt,
" With ſome beech Coales, leaſt the Veſſel buſt.
" If you can get theſe Ingredients, I'e compound them for you.
" Then when ſhe is perfectly recovered, ſhe ſhall be married
In rich cloth of Rainbow lac'd with Sun-beames.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: I hope Deſperato hath given her other Phyſick.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: Deſperato? is he her Phyſitian?
Since hope is dead, we all muſt to deſpair.

sp.speaker: Mod.
sp.l: Pardon the meſſenger if he relate
What he could wiſh were falſe. Morphe once was:
But after phyſick brought by Deſperato,
Raging and crying Amorous, She died.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: Lo now, believe your Cybill next.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: —If madneſs
Be now ſo near allied to prophecy,
I ſhall grow Prophet too. What angry Star
Thus frownes on all the Paſſions, moſt on me?
Ere ſince Prudentius dayes, we onely toil'd
In wretched mazes of confuſion,
Miſcheif, and diſcontent. I have not paſs'd
One hour in thoſe delights whereof I dream't;
And now the object of my happineſſe
Is clean extinct. But how? O there's the torment!
My torment's doubled through my ſelfe the cauſe.
Curs'd be my heedleſſe Love, which not content
With likely hopes, with honeſt wayes of wooing,
The wayes to long injoyning, headlong ran
To arts forbid. She had ſuch Innocence
Ev'n in her body, Temper ſo unforc'd,
That violent mixtures tending but to Love
To her were poyſons. Yet methinks, ſometimes,
There's Death in Deſperato's looks; perchance
He's divel in his dumps, as I in luſt.
Where ſhall we finde the bottom of our woe,
Who but on Paſſion have no ground to go!

div.head: SCENA I.
div.p: The Scene turnes to the houſe of Deſpair. A Table there laid.

sp.speaker: Deſp.
sp.l: Grow blacker yet my thoughts, grow blacker yet:
Your Plummets have not fadom'd the full depth
Of Paſſions miſery. I have invited them;
But I muſt chang their Cheere; and make it ſtronger
Then food and bare diſcourſe. I onely live
For others-death, and then I'le fill the heap
With mine own ruine: rather with mine eaſe:
For now the Paſſions flow like ſhoales of Fiſh
Into my net; they ſue to me for Counſel;
Ev'n to me; whoſe joy is in their death.
Juſt ſo the fearful Deere perſu'd with dogs,
Flies to the keepers lodg, a ſurer Fate.
To poyſon is dull art; my ſelfe am ſorry
For doing ill ſo poorly; my deſign
Is now more glorious; for I'le make them act
Their death upon themſelves, aud thank me for't
Amidſt their groanings. There have been with me
Fancie herſelfe, diſtracted for her Liveby;
Irato, Audax for maſſacring him;
Sir Timerous and Fuga for impatience
Of their abuſe. Unleſſe Recorder Memor
Skil'd in the Law, have wayes to ſcape my Nooſe,
I doubt of none. I've bid them to a Feaſt;
But ſuch a one, as Tantalus would ſhun;
Where I ſhall feed on all the gueſts that come.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Black Deſperato, did I lay two thrids
Upon thy ſpindle? haſt thou cut them both,
Morphe's and mine?

sp.speaker: Deſp.
sp.l: Why Sir, I mix'd your Philtre.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: She lives not me to love nor to be lov'd.
Didſt thou mix nothing elſe?

sp.speaker: Deſp.
sp.l: You know ſometimes
That Death and Cupid do miſtake their ſh ••• es:
Had I mix'd Poyſon too and ſerv'd two humours,
Both mine and yours, it might be well digeſted.—

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: If I had not a dear requeſt unto thee,
To give me of the ſame, I would exact
Thy life for hers, however it was ſpilt.

sp.speaker: Deſp.
sp.l: If I had not deſign'd to kill ſome others
Out of meer kindneſſe, thou ſhoulſt try my skill
Of letting blood as well as giving phyſick.
But ſince I owe thee kindneſſe out of hate,
Come to my Banquet, thou ſhalt have thy ſawce.
There thou ſhalt meet thy friend Malevolo,
Who ſhar'd in this, and gave as much for Poyſon
As you did for your Philtre. I dealt honeſtly,
And pleaſur'd Both. Come, thou ſhalt have thy ſawce.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Divel, I thank thee.—

sp.speaker: Deſp.
sp.l: —Now▪ Malevolo.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: To hate was ſtill my hony. But this gall
Of being hated totally of all,
I cannot bear: for now I cannot hurt,
Having no Credit. Give me from thy ſtore
A dram of Poyſon. I have been thy friend,
Let it be ſtrong.

sp.speaker: Deſp.
sp.l: Firſt ſhake hands you muſt
With all the Paſſions, or at leaſt make ſhew
Of formal reconcilement: ſtay a while,
My Gueſts and Cheer are coming.—

sp.speaker: Ir.
sp.l: —Have we found
This monſter here? we'l ſend thy ugly ſoul
Unto her fellow Feinds for tempting us.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: I prompted you to kill. Were not you ready
To do as bad as I could ſay? Meane while
I turn'd you from deſtroying one another.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Twas for thine one black Ends.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: And ſay it was:
Might not I hate, as well as you might kill?
My humour was as lawful.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Hadſt thou kept it
Home to thy ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: I labour not excuſe,
But accuſation of your equal Crimes.

sp.speaker: Deſp.
sp.l: He ſayes the right; and hoſpitality
Doth now require, ye ſhould deferr your Broyles.

div.head: SCENA V.
div.stage: Enter to them Fancie in the Tiremans Coronet, hair disſheveld, in black and Silver habit. Fuga, Amorous, Timerous.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: Sir, here's a Crown, (and tis the worſt of mine)
Not to be match'd in all the globe of heaven
Now ſhall I feed upon Ambroſia?
Moſt diveliſhly. What gods are theſe two Mars-es?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Hell is broke looſe; here are more Feinds then two.

sp.speaker: Fug.
sp.l: It ſhames me to look up; through griefe I cannot.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Wud I could die a ſleep in ſome darke hole
Unknown unto my ſelfe and all the world.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Malevolo, th' art damn'd.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: How know you that?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: And thou muſt ſinke to hell now inſtantly
For killing Morphe. Thou ſhalt drink the ſame
That very Poyſon.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Wel, ſo you'l begin.

div.head: SCENA VI.
div.stage: Enter Hilario before Melancholico and Concupiſcence, brought in a Sedan.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.l: Now Siſter you are right: now you can ſnuffle
' As well a Melancolico. Care of fiction
" With help of ſomewhat elſe hath brought perfection.
" None come in Pomp but you: weakeneſſe is ſtately.
" Twere brave if theſe two beaſts that draw without
" And theſe two rotten carcaſſes within
' Made it not look ſo Cart-like. My clean couple,
If you would be divorc'd, there's none can do't
Like Deſperato; he can ſeperate
At a worlds diſtance; that ye ner'e ſhall meet
To clamour me or others, or your ſelves.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: A pretty kinde of Coach; one horſe before
And one behinde!

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Horſes? why, theſe are Men.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: I ſee it now; it is the glaſſmans pack.
Have you good choice of Glaſſes, made in Figure
Of Guns and Trumpets, or of Rats and Owles?
Laſt time I ſaw the like, I bid a Gallant
Begin a health, and after break his glaſſe:
So did the reſt; but do not do ſo now,
Leaſt for a Glaſſe ſome ſhould miſtake a Lady.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.l: Femals are Venice mettle.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Theſe ſad men
Uſe to be ſumptuous in their Feaſts.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.l: And witty.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: I fear 'twill be too great.

sp.speaker: Ir.
sp.l: Too tedious.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Wellcome and bold I'le be.—

div.head: SCENA VII.
div.stage: Enter Deſperato before his banquet ſerv'd in cover'd diſhes,

sp.speaker: Deſp.
sp.l: —Aerious Queen,
Here are no Phoenix eggs; had nature any,
You ſhould have ſome: and eggs ſublim'd with Amber
I thought too mean. I have not now ſelected
Rare filling meats, but rarely phyſical,
And ſwiftly curing all the maladies
Which time can throw upon the face of man.
Each diſh containes a general remedy,
Beyond th' Elixir, or the golden Liquour,
Though it were drunk in th' Antimonial Cup.
Open and try.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: What's here? Knives, Bodkins, Daggers?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Ropes, ſilken, hairy, hempen?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Little papers,
Of witty, loving, raging, ſleeping poyſons?

sp.speaker: Deſp.
sp.l: There's Wine to temper them.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.l: So, where's the Wine?
I ſtill come ſomewhat merry to a Feaſt,
And ſtill go merrier back. This is my meſſe:
All this to all.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: Is this our entertainment?

sp.speaker: Deſp.
sp.l: Could Art invent, or Wealth procure you better?
The Greateſt, Wiſeſt, Stouteſt, and the faireſt
Have choſe theſe Cates to reliſh their laſt palats:
Have you not heard of Mithridates, Cato,
Of Hannibal, and Cleopatra? Theſe?
Theſe gods on earth have travl'd to their home
With ſuch proviſion. Taſt. One taſt of theſe
Forever frees from Hunger, Thirſt, Want, Griefe:
Theſe are receites for immortality.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: But through a mortal way.

sp.speaker: Deſp.
sp.l: That ſleeping Dos
Will ſteal thy fearful ſoul inſenſibly.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: Then that ſhall bear me hoodwink'd unto Lethe;
There I'le forget my wrongs.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.l: Manners however;
Firſt let the Queen begin. I broke that Rule
My ſelfe, and therefore m • m.—Well danc'd youd Scaffold.

sp.speaker: Deſp.
sp.l: Theſe things the moſt of you deſir'd; All want,
Y'are wellcome all.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.l: No, no more I thank you.

sp.speaker: Deſp.
sp.l: Death to the wretched ſoul as needful is,
As ſleep unto the weary. Why ſhould men
Condemnd to miſery thus toile to mend
Their Fates which cannot alter?

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.l: This Deſperate
What a gift he has! he never was at th' Univerſity;
Never took Orders, and yet lectures as good Divinity
As commonly we finde in moſt Dutch Syſtems
Or City-conventicles.

sp.speaker: Deſp.
sp.l: Pleaſes your Highneſſe
To chuſe and give the ſignal, that we all
May waite upon your dying.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: Reach me then
The witty poyſon.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Me the loving mixt;
That when I die, embracing her Idea,
My Soul may keep that print, and bear from hence
A heaven within me. He that ſtript of fleſh
And luſt ſtill loves, will ſhew true love indeed.
But you Malevolo ſhall take my part.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: My place in heaven is ſure; what need I haſt?
Yes, 'cauſe I live in hell.

sp.speaker: Deſp.
sp.l: Then take theſe banes
Mentioned before.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.l: Do; as good he poyſon thee
As thou elſe drown thy ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Poyſon I have too much,
Already, and in vain. Reach me your halter.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.l: Hoh hoh hoh; a halter? a dagger, he's ſo rotten,
He'l ne're hold hanging. Now for my part, ſleep
Kills me ſufficiently; Ile die before hand.

sp.speaker: Conc.
sp.l: In luſt I liv'd with man; to kill that ſin
Lend me that ponyard, ſo I'le manly die.

sp.speaker: Fug.
sp.l: This Bodkin is my husband; this alone
Shall know my fleſh, and finde I was a Virgin.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Come joyn Irato, as we liv'd lets hang,
Two nooſes and one rope will ſerve us both.

sp.speaker: Ir.
sp.l: Tis a dogs death, and therefore not unfit.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.l: Hoh hoh hoh.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Choice I neglect whatever can diſpatch
Loath'd life is ſweet. My hate would faine turn home,
But cannot: Still me thinks I feele content
In ſeeing ſuch a fruitful race of miſcheife,
Becauſe it ſprung from me. If Fancies madneſſe
Had not unhing'd the courſe of my deſign,
And brought remedileſſe confuſion
On all the Paſſions here at once; unſeen
Beloved and honor'd, I with Art and Pleaſure
Had done what Deſperato does by chance.
He onely held the Net; I hunted in
The ſtore of game: The praiſe is mine. And now
I die not with remorſe of hate, but want
Of objects to be hated. Thus the worme
Having conſum'd the Orb wherein it liv'd,
Doth laſtly turn its hunger on it ſelfe.
Should I ſurvive I could not finde more work,
Unleſſe I learn,d to pitty what is done.
That's worſe then death.

sp.speaker: Deſp.
sp.l: When I have rid you all,
If I ſlink off let all the world beſides
Fling ſtones. In ſuch good company to fall,
Muſt needs be lightſome. And before out death
A Hymne is neceſſary. Then ſing good Fellow.
An Attendant ſings in a baſe.
Come heavy ſouls oppreſſed with the weight
Of Crimes, or Pangs, or want of your delight,
Come down in Lethe's, ſleepy lake
Whatever makes you ake.
Drink health from poyſon'd bowles
Breathe out your cares together with your ſouls.
Cool Death's a ſalve
Which all may have
There's no diſtinction in the grave;
Lay down your loads before deaths iron dore,
Sigh, and ſigh out, groan once, and groan no more.

div.head: SCENA VIII.
div.stage: Enter towards the end of the ſong Intellectus Agens with a book. Livebyhope and Morphe.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Ha! thou com'ſt to challeng: but thou art ſpirit,
I cannot wound thee. Stay ſome few ſhort minutes,
Till I have quite undreſs'd me of my fleſh;
And ſtand on equal termes, then I will fight.
Elſe if thou canſt, kill me; and take my fleſh;
Then I'le kill thee again. Thus o're and o're
Wel'l kill each other and be ghoſts by turnes.

sp.speaker: Ir.
sp.l: My anger is not high: I onely gueſſ
He comes to ſhew the way to following ghoſts.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: I gave him once a houſe, my moſt remote,
Perchance 'tis in Elyſium, he invites me.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: But Morphe ſtands as if ſhe bid me come
Like a clear ſpirit fitly to ſalute her.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Why ſhould that ſight fling Ice into this heart?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.l: and Fug. O horrid!

sp.speaker: Deſp.
sp.l: Come what will, I can but die.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Hath this ſhrewd Scholer conjur'd up theſe ghoſts?

sp.speaker: Int.
sp.l: I ſee you are amazd; the ſnares of death
Are tangled on your hands: you think theſe ſights
A pair of ghoſts; feel, and when you feel them
True fleſh, alive and warme, next you muſt know
They are a token ſent from Prudentius.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: How? from Prudentius? hath he rais'd the dead
And wretched both at once? and ſent me Morphe?

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: And giv'n me hope again? a dainty ſhow,
Who'ere contriv'd it.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Be thou ſhade or ſubſtance,
Since thou appear'ſt in ſuch a lovely ſhap,
My ſoul I'e mingle with thine airy hand,
And ſtrive to ſuck from thence the hated poyſon.
But ſoft, I may do raſhly.

sp.speaker: Int.
sp.l: Know once more,
Theſe are not ghoſts, nor ever were; but live
Preſerv'd with care, and ſent with love from him,
Whom ye refus'd, your King Prudentius.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: By heav'n, true fleſh and warme.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: Why ſpeaks not Hope If he have breath?

sp.speaker: Ir.
sp.l: Speak: free us from thy blood,
For which we have been angry with our ſelves.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Speak, if thou canſt, thou muſt.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: I fear'd to ſtartle
Unſettled heads with unexpected ſpeech.
High Miſtreſſe, your diſtracted griefe for me
Had almoſt kill'd me when I was recover'd.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: I am recover'd by this voice.
Then tell me
Thy preſervation.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Audax and Irato
Know how they left me.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Kill us for amends:

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Alas your death's would profit me no more
Then mine could you: but gracious Intellectus
Found and releiv'd me, while Sir Amorous
Carri'd in Morphe.

sp.speaker: Int.
sp.l: Him I took up gaſping
Temper'd like Ice before it thaw and crack,
In ſuch a glimmering ſtate of doubtful life.
As Candles have before they blaze and vaniſh.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Theſe ropes will all be mine.

sp.speaker: Int.
sp.l: And her I ſav'd.
By looking on her mixt and poyſnous phyſick.
The ſimples I extracted, and gave out
The ſame effect which likely would have follow'd.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Pardon my fault, I nothing mixt but love,
Thoſe villaines added poiſon.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Heav'n forgive
As I forgive you all.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Give me ſome poyſon, (Int. Liv. and Mor. ſtay him. You ſtay me too?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Although I love thee not
Beyond an honeſt man, I cannot ſee
Thee die neglected.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.l: What a coile is here
With ghoſts? I cannot take my reſt for ghoſts.
People, y'ar wellcome to this world. How fare
My fellow ſleepers, ghoſts, your Countrymen.

sp.speaker: Int.
sp.l: Thank not my care for this, but thank Prudentius;
Ask not what Genius ſent me to releive
Expiring Hope, it was Prudentius:
Ask not what ſtar compell'd my timely viſit
Of Morphe poyſon-trap'd, it was Prudentius.
From him proceeds their preſervation;
And yours in them. Snatch'd from the jawes of death
As lights blown in again you live through him.
This is your caſt-away, your droſſe, Prudentius.

sp.speaker: Ir.
sp.l: I think we wrong'd him in our heedleſſe anger.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: And yet his love ſeems payment for deſert.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: How ſhall I rule this craz'd and tottring State?

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: I ſmell in what half point the wind is turning.
One breath will carry all the Paſſions
Back to Prudentius ſailes. Now for a fetch.
Well, I'le prevent them all. Call back Prudentius,
Let's ſue to him for grace.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Call back Prudentius.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Tis quickly done. If this way lead to peace
I opend it; but ſtill I would ſtand ſafer.
Audax, you have a Drum. Now do not you
And Lord Irato end your buſineſſe ſneaking.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: Liveby you kept the Crownes: go with him Amorous,
Carry his own: I ne're eſteem'd the Golden.
I can be Queen alone, and govern ſubjects.
Of mine own making; more, then Kings can muſter
Or Earth bring forth.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: I'le take Recorder Memor
To lay our ſute in form. Then on our knees
We'l beg to ſerve him ſo, ev'n ſo forever.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.l: Come, to our old new Sun.

sp.speaker: Int.
sp.l: He's in his Court;
And now me thinks his preſence guilds the walls.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Though weak we'l go along.

sp.speaker: Conc.
sp.l: Weake legs can kneel.

sp.speaker: Deſp.
sp.l: This peice of mine own banquet le aſſume
And walk in penance of a ſolemn halter.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Ile go ſome neerer way, and recompence
My forward breach with much more forward duty.
For this Event ſpun out by Intellectus
Makes me think honeſty may weigh with cunning.
Some ſheep, ſome Fox will make a perfect man.
Howe're, me thinkes, theſe Sword-men might compound
Our Peace in Armes, and plead with violence.

div.head: SCENA. IX.
div.stage: The Scene returns to Prudentius his Court.
Enter one way Prudentius, Memor with the Crown, Intellectus, Livebyhope, Amorous with the Sword. By another way Malevolo ſoon after.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: Without a Seizin no poſſeſſion.
Your Crown is undefil'd, untouch'd.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.l: Place thou
The world in my ballance, place in theirs
All Levity, then weigh them both. Next tell me
How ended thoſe commotions which aroſe
Betwixt the third King Henry and his Rebells?

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: He ſentenc'd his Metropolis to flames
Their goods to his Exchequer, and their lives—

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.l: No more. Should I do ſo? do not I know
What doomes have paſs'd upon untruſty
Lawyers?—

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: I Sink before your mercy, be't like Henries.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Kneeling is but a Subjects Complement. I ſink.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: And I.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: we might have ſtay'd to hear What means this Drum.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: —We have deſcri'd a Fleet;
And therefore call'd to armes.

sp.speaker: Ir.
sp.l: Submiſſively
We proſtrate our repentance with a ſute,
That I and Audax may decide in Duel
Who ſhall be ſacrific'd for both to juſtice,
And the Surviver may be General.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.l: The Fleet which you ſuſpect, is your defence;
Unknown to you I ſent it forth to guard
This Iſland from the dangers you have call'd,
By Tumult, Luſt, Debate, and Diſcontent.
As for your Duel, 'tis a Savadg fury
By us forbid. But you have lately tri'd
A new found Duel, (was it honourable?)
Two upon one. Or was it Captain like
To kill a friend? In any likely way
Hope would have further'd Audax: but when boldneſſe
Growes impudent it turns a foe to Hope.

div.head: SCENA XI.
div.stage: Enter Fancie, Fuga, Hilario, Timerous, Melancholico and Concupiſcence. Soon after Deſperato.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: King of Affections:—

sp.speaker: Pru:
sp.l: Queen of Inventions.—

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: Unleſſe you think your ſelfe beholding to me
You are not fit to be my King. The
Paſſions
I have ſo ſuffer'd in abſurdity,
That now they beg your reign which they ſhook off.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.l: I ſee there is ſome mirth in miſery.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: I kneel unto your grace to uſe me ſo,
As one that hath been Queen, and yet no Queeen,
Rather a ſhew then Soveraign. I walk'd
But in mock-majeſty. Say it were true,
I ſought it not, and what is worth a taking
If not a Kingdom?

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.l: Down my frolick joynts,
Kneeling is now in faſhion. Down, down Fuga;
Concupiſcence and Melancholico
Favour your ſelves with kneeling.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: I kneel not
To thee, but to thy power; I kneel to thee
But not adore thee.

sp.speaker: Conc.
sp.l: Pardon.

sp.speaker: Deſp.
sp.l: —Thus attir'd
I wear my ſentence. Sir, I can but offer
That power of doome which I my ſelfe might take.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.l: If you ask pardon, ask it of your
Prince;
For I nor am, nor will be.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Royal Sir,
Why have you giv'n us lives, if not to take
Or to preſerve them?

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: Hope, ſpeak for us Hope.

sp.speaker: Liv.
sp.l: Be pleas'd thou god on earth.

sp.speaker: Int.
sp.l: I likewiſe joyn
In this requeſt.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.l: Ile ſend them Epimetheus
My Brother Afterwit; and he ſhall rule them.
Thoſe fooles whom Prudence cannot prereſtrain,
The laſh of Afterwit brings home again.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: We'l die upon this place.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: And each man turn
To his own grave.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.l: Do, and do not burden
Me with new cares for new Rebellion.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: We grone unto you?

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.l: Why? for here are many
That would be Kings, Amorous, this gay thing,
Which overlookes a
Kingdom, may command
All Choice of pleaſure: take it for that uſe:
No? then Malevolo to devour your flock,
T' ingroſſe the Elements, and let none breath
That may reſiſt, and onely ſpare a few
That may for fear do ſervice, i'ſt not glorious?
Work with this Engine. No? are you grown modeſt?
Then Deſperato, what a life it is
To have the power of hanging, or of cauſing
Some to prevent the gallowes in their priſon.
What, hang your head ſo dully at a Crown.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.l: This is to offer Sallets unto dogs.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.l: Irato, anger is a Kings perfection
As roaring is the Lions. When his eye
Darts lightning, when he ſnaps his dagger hard
Cries hah and ſtarts, doth he not then ſeem god like,
And well deſerve the name of Thunderer?
Be thou that Jove. Not you? Then Captain Audax.
You took great pains to win, now weare this Crown.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Any but yours I would.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.l: Could ye get Crownes
Abroad as ſoon as pull off one at home,
Ye ſhould be Kings or Deputies all over.
Now there can be but one: would that be Memor.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.l: In all records I finde no Lawyer Crown'd.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.l: A Lawyer needs it not: to pen the Law,
And then interpret it as much as making.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.l: Fancie you muſt be troubled once again
With this bright loade.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.l: I loath'd it at the firſt.
Grant me the Soveraignty of changing faſhions,
Promotion of new Projects, leave to weare
Such Coronets at theſe, I ask no more.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.l: When I am King, be this thy Royalty.
Poor Diadem, ſince here thou canſt not get
A Maſter, lye thou there for the next commer,
Or ſink into thy Oare.—None ſtoop
to take thee?
What all refuſe, I once refus'd of all
Am fit to wear.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Long live Prudentius.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.l: Then once more chain'd in Gold, Ile bear your burden.
Henchforth to awe your folly, be aſſur'd,
None of your crooked actions words or lookes
Hath ſcap'd my notice. They camefreſh unto me
With tongues of ſpirits: But Ile leave the chiding
To your own Conſcience. Now, thus reconcil'd,
I'le pardon your deſerts, cannot reward them.
If you expect in ſign of peaceſome matches
You are deceiv'd. Amorous ſhall not wed
Morphe, without a faire probation.
And Timerous I forbid; ſuch muſt not marry
As have no mettle, leaſt they ſpoile their race.
But Melancolico and Concupiſcence
Shall keep their ſtate; i'th ſuburbs, or new-England.
Now riſe. For ſhew of future correſpondence,
Rank your ſelves friendly with your oppoſites.—

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.l: I live not by my line of life, but yours.

sp.speaker: Mal.
sp.l: Love is a willing Paſſion, full of ſweetneſſe,
But not ſo ſerviceable as loyal hate;
This loves with zeal and with compariſon,
Works againſt all for one. to ſerve your State
Let others love, whilſt I for you ſhall hate;
My ſelfe, if that you pleaſe; and others ſo,
That hate with vertue hand in hand ſhall go.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.l: Tis well, tis very well. Live as you look,
Irato beare the Sword: I'le view them all.
Thus betwixt love of good, and hate of ill.
With ſlight of this; and chaſt deſire of that,
With ſadneſſe to be wiſe, joy for good ends
Boldneſſe for juſt attemps, Feare of unfit;
Hope for true peace, deſpair of nothing leſſe
Then meer Impoſſibilities, we'l walk
To Immortality upon thoſe lines
Which a wiſe Princes breaſt nought elſe defines.

div.stage:
Exeunt Omnes.
A Scheme of Poſture.
Prudentius
Fancie
Amorous
Concupiſcence
Hilario
Audax
Livebyhope
Irato
Intellectus
Memor
Malevolo
Fuga
Melancolico
Timerous
Deſperato

div.head: After the muſick ended, the Iſland appearing Setled. Enter the Epiloge. To His Majeſty.
div.l: BY this ſhort Model of ſelf-policy,
We find what uſe of Outward Soveraignty.
The Iſle is ſetled, rage of Paſſion, laid,
And Phancy ſtoopes to Prudence. Things ſo ſtaid,
Our Scene which was but Fiction now is true;
No King ſo much Prudentius as you:
Whoſe Rule is Reaſon, Throne the heart; And now
No ſouls ſo Paſſionate as we; that bow
Both with the weight of Duty and of Debt.
Henceforth our hearts all motion ſhall forget
But yours. Your Rule alone is fit to ſway;
Yet we no leſſe your benefits obey.
Twixt both, our loyalty will nameleſs prove;
That makes it Vertue, theſe will have it Love.

div.head: To the Univerſity.
div.l: THe Iſle is ſetled, Rage of Paſſions laid
Phancy to Prudence bowes. Let all be ſtaid
In your Acceptance too, and then each breaſt
Will ceaſe its Floating, and as firmly reſt
As doth our Scene. One Paſſion ſtill would prove
An Actor when the Scene is ſhut, Our Love.
